ntc2.welcome.title: Welcome to &fNTC2&r
ntc2.welcome.subtitle: Thank you for playing!
ntc2.welcome.desc1: Lets forget about your problems for a while and immerse yourself into this modpack
ntc2.welcome.desc2: &fNTC2&r is a modpack completely designed with love, with carefully designed recipes that provide a unique playing experience
ntc2.main.title: &6Main Quests&r
ntc2.main.subtitle: These are &bquests&r that &6must&r be completed in order to progress
ntc2.optional.title: &6Optional Quests&r
ntc2.optional.subtitle: &bCompletely&r optional. These will mainly be &6tips and tricks&r

ntc2.gotoquests.subtitle: &bRound quests&r will take you to &6another page&r
ntc2.stone.subtitle: &eEMCable&r
ntc2.stone.desc1: Gather Stone to make Sturdy Stone
ntc2.beds.title: Warding off the &5Nightmares&r
ntc2.beds.subtitle: &oI'm not sleeping! I'm just squishing a bug with my eyelids&r
ntc2.watercan.title: &bWatercans!&r
ntc2.watercan.subtitle: Whoa, whats in this stuff?!
ntc2.watercan.desc1: Michael Jordans Secret Stuff? Probably not, but plants love these!
ntc2.inksac.desc1: After completing &n&aOn the Dynamics of Integration&r Guide book, you will get a &bsquid and some ink&r
ntc2.cobble.subtitle: &eEMCable&r
ntc2.cobble.desc1: Gather Cobblestone to make Sturdy Stone
ntc2.saplings.title: &bOne&r of every &6kind&r
ntc2.saplings.desc1: Easily transmute any sapling you get with the Philosophers Stone into other variants
ntc2.feather.desc1: If you haven't figured it out already. The &bPhilosophers Stone&r is capable of &6morphing&r animals and monsters into another. What was once a Pig is now a Chicken, or a Cow, or a Zombie...?
ntc2.feather.desc2: Passive mobs spawn naturally given some time and enough space. If you happen to come across a chicken and get some feathers before completing the &n&aBook&r quest, congrats
ntc2.backpack.title: &bSophisticated Backpacks!&r
ntc2.backpack.desc1: &fSophisticated backpacks is yet another backpack mod this time with backpack you can place in world, color in different color combinations, upgrade with more inventory and enhance with many functional upgrades.&r
ntc2.backpack.desc2:
&l&bBackpack in its item form:&r
Can be accessed using a key press (by default B)
Renders on player when put in their chest slot
Curios compatibility makes it possible to wear and render the backpack when put in “Back” slot
ntc2.backpack.desc3:
&l&bBackpack can also be placed in world:&r
Shift right clicking the backpack on the ground puts it down
When in world player can use it the same way they would use a chest
Backpacks can also have items piped in/out using hoppers or any kind of modded pipes, external storage access..
Shift right clicking the backpack on the ground with empty hand picks it back up or it can also be brokend and picked up as any other item
ntc2.backpack.desc4:
&l&bBackpacks can be upgraded:&r
5 tiers - leather, iron, gold, diamond, netherite
Each of the tiers adds more storage slots and more upgrade slots
ntc2.backpack.desc5:
&l&bLoot / Mob Spawning:&r
Occasionally backpacks and some upgrades can be found in loot chests
And even though rare, mobs can also spawn with backpacks on them sometimes with a bit of loot in those and sometimes they would even play a tune
ntc2.backpack.desc6:
&l&bDyeing the backpack in crafting table:&r
Color of multiple dyes in recipe gets combined similar to how it works for coloring leather armor except backpack can have two colors - main and accent
Dyes to the left of the backpack in the recipe apply to the main color
Dyes to the right apply to the accent color of the backpack
Dyes in the same column apply to both
And once dyed you can continue adding dyes which combine with the current main color, accent color or both
So yes there are many color combinations
Color of already dyed backpack can be washed away by clicking it on cauldron with water
ntc2.backpack.desc7:
&l&bUpgrades:&r
Pickup Upgrade
Magnet Upgrade
Filter Upgrade
Void Upgrade
Compacting Upgrade
Feeding upgrade
Deposit upgrade
Restock Upgrade
Refill upgrade
Inception Upgrade
Everlasting Upgrade
Smelting Upgrades
Crafting Upgrade
Stonecutter Upgrade
Stack Upgrade
Jukebox Upgrade
Toolswapper Upgrade
ntc2.sturdy.subtitle: &7Stone&r that makes sense
ntc2.furnace.subtitle: Good ole &6Furnace&r
ntc2.quartz.desc1: &bNether Quartz&r can be found in the &2Nether&r of course, but you first get it from sieving &6Soul Sand&r in an &dIron mesh&r. &cDon't even try a &dFlint mesh&r &cunless you want to lose all your &6Soul Sand&r
ntc2.quartz.desc2: &6Soul Sand&r can be acquired from putting &eSand&r in a barrel of &5witch water&r, you will get &d64x&r more from completing the quest
ntc2.redstoneingot.subtitle: Required to make the &6Piston&r
ntc2.clayball.desc1: &bClay block&r can be first acquired from inserting &6dust&r into a barrel of &1water&r, then simply break it down normally
ntc2.terracottaplate.subtitle: Can be used to make early game &bplate casts&r for &eTinkers&r
ntc2.cocoabeans.subtitle: Sieve &eSand&r to get &6Cocoa Beans&r
ntc2.nethergems.subtitle: Can be found in the &2Nether&r early game
ntc2.potassiumnitrate.desc1: Can be found in the &2Nether/Overworld&r. Created with &eProductive Bees&r and &eMystical Agriculture&r, and by grinding up &6Sandstone&r
ntc2.sulfur.desc1: Can be found in the &2Nether/Overworld&r. Created with &bOil processing&r, &bChemical processing&r, &eMystical Agriculture, Productive Bees&r, and grinding up &6Blaze Rods&r
ntc2.grindstone.title: &o&bManual Grinding&r
ntc2.grindstone.subtitle: Make a Quartz Grindstone
ntc2.grindstone.desc1: The &bQuartz Grindstone&r is the &6earliest form of ore duplication&r in most packs it's in
ntc2.grindstone.desc2: Simply insert the items you wish to crush into the left slots, place a &bCrank&r on top of the block, and then hold right-click on the Crank
ntc2.grindstone.desc3: This will slowly grind the blocks, turning them to dust. If there are no inputs, this has a chance of destroying the Crank
ntc2.grindstone.desc4: This block can be tick accelerated with things such as &eTime in a Bottle&r
ntc2.sand.subtitle: Lets go to the &eBeach!&r Oh wait...
ntc2.sand.desc1: Place &7Cobblestone&r down and right click with the &bPhilosophers Stone&r to make it into &eSand&r
ntc2.sandstone.subtitle: Sandstone into Gravel
ntc2.sandstone.desc1: Place Sandstone down and right click with the Philosophers Stone to make it into gravel.
ntc2.gravel.subtitle: Gravel into Flint
ntc2.flint.subtitle: 2 Flint into Crafting Table
ntc2.flint.desc1: Maybe you'll get lucky and break a gravel and get some flint
ntc2.plank.title: Any Planks
ntc2.plank.subtitle: &eEMCable&r

ntc2.sawmill.subtitle: Makes Stripped and Wood logs easier to get

ntc2.pot.subtitle: A very easy &eEMC&r farm

ntc2.poweredpot.subtitle: Another better even better &eEMC&r farm option
ntc2.gototicon.title: &fGo To&r &n&aTinkers Construct Chapter&r
ntc2.gotoie.title: &fGo To&r &n&aImmersive Engineering Chapter&r
ntc2.gotoie.desc: You're going to need these nuggets to build the hammer. So don't accidentally drop them.
ntc2.gotointdyn.title: &fGo To&r &n&aIntegrated Dynamics Chapter&r
ntc2.gotobeegees.title: &fGo To&r &n&aBee'Gees Chapter&r
ntc2.gotofanscan.title: &fGo To&r &n&aFantastic Scans Chapter&r
ntc2.gotoae2.title: &fGo To&r &n&aApplied Energistics 2 Chapter&r
ntc2.hc2.title: &fGo To&r &n&aHarvestcraft 2 Chapter&r
ntc2.morefurnaces.title: &fGo To&r &n&aMore Furnaces Chapter&r
ntc2.pollution.title: &fGo To&r &n&aPollution Chapter&r
ntc2.agricraft.title: &fGo To&r &n&aAgricraft Chapter&r
ntc2.fluxnetworks.title: &fGo To&r &n&aFlux Networks Chapter&r
ntc2.gotothermal.title: &fGo To&r &n&aThermals Chapter&r
ntc2.gotocompact.title: &fGo To&r &n&aCompact Machines Chapter&r
ntc2.gotoindust.title: &fGo To&r &n&aIndustrial Foregoing Chapter&r
ntc2.gotoae2.desc1: Meteors don't spawn in the world and inscriber plates must be crafted.
ntc2.amourarmour.title: Amour Armors
ntc2.amourarmour.desc2: Defense points are each signified by half of a shirt of mail in the armor bar above the health bar. Each defense point reduces any damage dealt to the player that is absorbed by armor by 4%%, increasing additively with the number of defense points. Different materials and combinations of armor provide different levels of defense.
ntc2.iealloykiln.title: Alloy Kiln
ntc2.iealloykiln.subtitle: Early Game Alloys
ntc2.iealloykiln.desc1: You're gonna need a &bHammer&r. &fGo To&r &n&aImmersive Engineering Chapter&r
ntc2.iealloykiln.task:
Look at a completed Alloy Kiln                      
8x Kiln Bricks
ntc2.bronzealloy.subtitle: Combine &b3 x&r &6Copper&r and &b1 x&r &aTin&r to make the &dBronze&r Alloy
ntc2.bronzealloy.desc1: Consequently, having the &bHammer&r enables you to make &ddust&r with the 4 components to create a dust &dblend&r.
ntc2.bronzealloy.desc2: However to claim the &eEMC&r value for the &6Copper&r and &aTin&r ingots, convert the &6Copper&r and &aTin&r Chunks into ingot forms.
ntc2.bronzealloy.desc3: &oJust in case you screwed that up you are awarded 1 x &6Copper&r and &aTin&r Ingots
ntc2.sugarcaneseed.title: Sugarcane Seeds
ntc2.sugarcaneseed.subtitle: Sieve Dirt to get sugarcane seeds
ntc2.cactusseed.title: Cactus Seeds
ntc2.crucibles.title: The Crucible
ntc2.stonebarrel.subtitle: Required for molten fluids
ntc2.redstone.desc1: Redstone Chunks can be awarded from completing the Drying Basin. Congratulations on getting redstone, this will bring you to automation!
ntc2.redstone.desc2: Redstone can also be acquired from sifting Dust with an Iron Mesh.
ntc2.akashic.subtitle: All in one place
ntc2.akashic.desc1: A place to store all your books and wrenches.
ntc2.pollution.subtitle: Things that burn make pollution
ntc2.pollution.desc1: You might have noticed that the furnaces spit out some carbon and sulfur pollution now and again. You might want to get a handle on that before it gets too bad.
ntc2.pollution.desc2: Eating, dying, killing creatures and machines all produce some level of dust, carbon or sulfur. Among other pollutants..
ntc2.paper.desc1: Your reward for making paper is rabbit hide!
ntc2.wands.subtitle: Cut out the tedious platform building
ntc2.coal.desc1: Craft 4 Charcoal and the Philosophers Stone together to imbue Coal
ntc2.mushrooms.desc1: You can get mushrooms several ways:
ntc2.mushrooms.desc2: Throw ancient seeds into a barrel of witchwater to get brown mushroom block, break the brown block for a brown mushroom.
ntc2.mushrooms.desc3: The nether naturally spawns them, you can also bone meal nylium to get the fungus varieties.
ntc2.mushrooms.desc4: The philosophers stone randomizer can get you a mooshroom, set up a little farm of them will yield red/brown mushrooms.
ntc2.mushrooms.desc5: Bonemealing Mycelium will yield red/brown mushrooms.
ntc2.mushrooms.desc6: Agricraft, crop mutation between potatoes and carrots.
ntc2.rabbit.desc1: Rabbit hide can be acquired from the paper quest.
ntc2.lava.subtitle: Place Obsidian down and right click with the Philosophers Stone to make it into lava. Make sure you have a bucket handy to pick it up right away!
ntc2.lava.desc1: If you use this method, it should go without saying you should probably not build your platform out of wood.
ntc2.lava2.title: What came first? Lava or Obsidian?
ntc2.lava2.subtitle: I dont care how you get it, just get it...
ntc2.lava2.desc1: &4Lava&r can be achieved in many ways early game. You could melt one of your &5Obsidian&r flooring at spawn. Or you can use the &bCrucible&r and melt down stuff to make &4Lava&r.
ntc2.water.subtitle: &bWater Physics&r
ntc2.water.desc1: Not only is getting water sources different but gravity also affects water.
ntc2.blueice.subtitle: One of the prerequisites for crafting basalt
ntc2.blitz.subtitle: Pour Liquid XP over Potassium Nitrate Dust
ntc2.blizz.subtitle: Pour Liquid XP over Snowball
ntc2.blaze.subtitle: Pour Liquid XP over Sulfur Dust
ntc2.sieves.title: &bSieves of Paradise&r
ntc2.sieves.subtitle: A source of materials and genetics for bees
ntc2.ancientspores.subtitle: Dirt into Seeds
ntc2.mycelium.subtitle: Using Ancient Spores on Dirt
ntc2.oakbarrel.subtitle: Turning water... into FUNK! -John 2:1-11
ntc2.witchwater.subtitle: Collect Witchwater
ntc2.soulsand.subtitle: Witchwater into Soulsand
ntc2.dust.subtitle: Use the &bQuartz Grindstone&r to make &6Dust&r
ntc2.clay.subtitle: Use &6Dust&r in a barrel the &bQuartz Grindstone&r to make &6Dust&r
ntc2.greenslimeblock.subtitle: Mushrooms into Green Slime
ntc2.flintsteel.subtitle: Actually &fSteel&r
ntc2.visitnether.title: &2Visit Dimension:&r &eThe Nether&r
ntc2.endportal.subtitle: Buy it, use it, break it, fix it, trash it, change it, mail, upgrade it
ntc2.visitend.title: &2Visit Dimension:&r &eThe End&r
ntc2.chunks.subtitle: &dChunks&r drop instead of ore blocks
ntc2.solfood.subtitle: Food Overhaul - &6^&r Edition
ntc2.solfood.desc1: A mod designed to encourage dietary variety! It does so by rewarding the player for eating a variety of foods instead of punishing them for failing to diversify.
ntc2.solfood.desc2: The mod keeps track of how many unique foods a player has eaten. As they pass certain milestone amounts of unique foods, they permanently gain new hearts, increasing their max health! In order to max out their HP bars, players will have to quest for and craft exotic foods.
ntc2.heart.subtitle: Wait... This isn't Zelda. &oCtrl+Alt+Del&r
ntc2.heart.desc1: Tantrum brings also Heart Containers in the game to give the player the chance to get stronger!
ntc2.mycelium.title: Look at some Mycelium
ntc2.honeycomb.desc1: Currently, &6Bees&r spawn in &ePlains&r, &eSunflower Plains&r with a &b5%% chance&r for a &nnest&r to spawn on either &dbirch or oak trees&r, &oeven ones planted by you&r, they &lMUST&r be grown near &cflowers&r. You can also use a porcelain doll to spawn a &6Bee&r.
ntc2.honeycomb.desc2: Other Biomes chances are Flower Forest at 2%%, As well as Forest, Wooded Hills, Birch Forest, Tall Birch Forest, Birch Hills, Tall Birch Hills at 0.2%%
ntc2.ironingot.desc1: &fIron&r is first introduced as a &dnugget&r in the &fGo To&r &n&aImmersive Engineering Chapter&r. You don't get your first &bIron Chunks&r until completing the &mS&rmelter&my&r quest in Tinkers' Construct 3 chapter.
ntc2.ironingot.desc2: Consequently, as you have the &dPhilosophers Stone&r, you can &etransmute&r iron into gold, into diamond, into emerald. Iron can also be transmuted into an Ender Pearl.
ntc2.ironingot.desc3: &oThis is a huge milestone as Iron unlocks many things!&r
ntc2.obsidian.desc0: Obsidian can be acquired from putting water on top of a stone barrel filled with lava.
ntc2.obsidian.desc1: Oh by the way, this can be mined from any pickaxe level Iron and above. That's basically all Tier 2 materials and above.
ntc2.pipez.title: &b&nA couple of hard pipe-hitting n*****s&r
ntc2.pipez.subtitle: Your first method of transfer. Potentially.
ntc2.pipez.desc1: Despite Integrated Dynamics, this mod adds simple, &nearly game&r and highly configurable pipes that are designed to create as little lag as possible.
ntc2.pipez.desc2:
&l&bPipe Types:&r    
Item Pipes    
Fluid Pipes    
Energy Pipes    
Gas Pipes (Mekanism)    
Universal Pipes (All 4 Pipes in one!)
ntc2.pipez.desc3:
&l&bBasic Upgrade:&r    
Redstone modes 

&l&bImproved Upgrade:&r    
Distribution modes 

&l&bAdvanced Upgrade:&r    
Filter modes    
Filters 

&l&bFilters:&r 
Filters can be used with item pipes, fluid pipes and gas pipes.
ntc2.skyslime.desc1: &bSkyslimes&r can be created in a stone barrel with molten slime(green) and mixing it with Cyan dye.
ntc2.matsandyou.subtitle: Make Materials and You
ntc2.matsandyou.desc1: &bMaterials and You&r is the first of the mod's guide books.
ntc2.matsandyou.desc2: Apparently some Tinker's knowledge has been lost. Perhaps more will be remembered with newer versions.
ntc2.partbuilder.subtitle: Make the Part Builder
ntc2.partbuilder.desc1: The &bPart Builder&r is where you &6make lower-tier tool parts&r. Basically, anything that isn't metal.
ntc2.partbuilder.desc2: Place a &bPattern&r in the left slot, &6choose which part&r you want to make out of the list, then &6insert the material&r you want to make a part of.
ntc2.partbuilder.desc3: Only tier 1 materials can be used in the Part Builder, check Materials and You for a list.
ntc2.partbuilder.desc4: On the right, you can &6see the material's stats&r. You can hover over lines to see more information on them.
ntc2.partbuilder.desc5: Take the part out of the right slot to craft it, using up the materials and Pattern.
ntc2.mattiers.title: &bEncyclopedia of Tinkering&r
ntc2.mattiers.subtitle: Make the Encyclopedia of Tinkering
ntc2.mattiers.desc1: The &bEncyclopedia of Tinkering&r shows &6all tools, materials, and modifiers&r from all tiers.
ntc2.mattiers.desc2: &nTier 1 materials&r are common and simple, and need nothing more than a &6Part Builder&r.
ntc2.mattiers.desc3: &nTier 2 materials&r require &6melting and casting&r to make.
ntc2.mattiers.desc4: &nTier 3 materials&r require &6alloying&r, through an Alloyer or Smeltery.
ntc2.partchest.subtitle: Make a Part Chest
ntc2.partchest.desc1: The &bPart Chest&r can &6store Parts&r in stacks of up to 16.
ntc2.partchest.desc2: When placed adjacent to other Tinker's tables, you can &6swap between them all&r inside the GUI of any.
ntc2.modchest.subtitle: Make a Modifier Chest
ntc2.modchest.desc1: The &bModifier Chest&r can &6store items that can be used as modifiers&r in stacks of up to 16.
ntc2.modchest.desc2: Granted, some items (like Redstone) really don't do much 16 at a time, so it's not the most useful thing.
ntc2.tinkerstation.subtitle: Make a Tinker Station
ntc2.tinkerstation.desc1: The &bTinker Station&r is where you combine parts to &6make tools&r.
ntc2.tinkerstation.desc2: &6Select the tool&r you want to make on the left, then &6insert the parts&r in the center.
ntc2.tinkerstation.desc3: Along the right, you can &6see the tool's stats and modifiers&r.
ntc2.modifiers.title: Modifier Types
ntc2.modifiers.subtitle: Learn about the types of modifiers
ntc2.modifiers.desc2: &6Upgrades&r give some kind of boost, like speed, damage, etc. These &6take up Upgrade slots&r.
ntc2.modifiers.desc3: &6Abilities&r give more unique, well, abilities. These are things like fortune, silk touch, autosmelting, etc. These &6take up Ability slots&r, which are harder to come by.
ntc2.modifiers.desc4: &6Free&r modifiers don't take up any slots of any kind whatsoever. These tend to be somewhat weaker (like making your tool glow), or passive (like &ogiving you more upgrade slots&r).
ntc2.modifiers.desc5: &6Traits&r are inherent to a part's material. Stone parts always give Stonebound, Flint always gives Jagged, etc. Sometimes, materials may have lower stats but a better trait as a trade-off.
ntc2.tinkersanvil.title: Tinker's Anvil
ntc2.tinkersanvil.subtitle: Make a Tinker's Anvil
ntc2.tinkersanvil.desc1: The &bTinker's Anvil&r is used to &6make more complex tools&r.
ntc2.tinkersanvil.desc2: Other than that, it works basically the same as the Tinker Station. The difference in material is only aesthetic.
ntc2.melter.title: &mS&rmelter&my&r
ntc2.melter.subtitle: Make the Melter
ntc2.melter.desc1: The &bMelter&r is a multiblock that allows you to &6melt metals into fluids&r.
ntc2.melter.desc2: The &bFluid Tank&r supersedes the solid fuel - &bSeared Heater&r almost immediately. Melting points for the entire pack have been modified to be more realistic as well as changing progression.
ntc2.melter.desc3: It can smelt up to 3 items at a time, and can hold 9 ingots' worth of molten metal.
ntc2.melter.desc4: Additionally, &6melting ores will produce an additional 1/3 of an ingot&r.
ntc2.meltingpnt.title: Melting Points
ntc2.meltingpnt.subtitle: README
ntc2.meltingpnt.desc1: Melting points in this pack have entirely changed.
ntc2.casting.title: Casting
ntc2.casting.subtitle: Cast some molten metal
ntc2.casting.desc1: To &ouse&r molten metal, place a &bSeared Faucet&r on the Melter (or whatever block is storing the fluid).
ntc2.casting.desc2: Place the &bCasting Table&r or &bCasting Basin&r underneath.
ntc2.casting.desc3: If a recipe requires inserting an item into the Table/Basin, insert it. &6Right-click the Faucet&r to pour the metal into the Table/Basin.
ntc2.casting.desc4: To make tool parts, you need &bCasts&r. There are two types of Cast: Sand and Gold.
ntc2.casting.desc5: &6Sand Casts&r can only be used once, but are very cheap. To use them, insert a &6Blank Sand Cast&r onto the Table, then &6use a Part&r on it.
ntc2.casting.desc6: This will essentially make a hole in the Cast in the shape of the Part, making a Sand Cast for it. Pour the molten metal on this to create the Part.
ntc2.casting.desc7: &bGold Casts&r are reusable but more expensive. Insert a Part onto an empty Table, and &6pour Molten Gold on it&r.
ntc2.casting.desc8: This will destroy the Part, but makes a Gold Cast of that Part.
ntc2.smeltbooks.title: I'm dirty, mean, I'm mighty unclean
ntc2.smeltbooks.subtitle: Make the next two Books
ntc2.smeltbooks.desc1: &bPuny Smelting&r has a list of all &6Tier 2 materials&r, information on the Melter, as well as &6upgrade and slotless modifiers&r.
ntc2.smeltbooks.desc2: &bMighty Smelting&r has &6Tier 3&r, information on the Smeltery, &6Broad Tools&r (tools that need the Tinker's Anvil), and &6ability modifiers&r..
ntc2.smeltery.title: Smeltery
ntc2.smeltery.subtitle: Make a Smeltery
ntc2.smeltery.desc1: The &bSmeltery&r is a multiblock that &6melts metals&r and &6combines molten metals into alloys&r.
ntc2.smeltery.desc2: Its shape is much more freeform than the Melter. Basically, make any rectangular shape out of &bSeared Blocks&r (anywhere from 1x1 to 13x13 internal).
ntc2.smeltery.desc3: Then, one block above and one layer out (so it's placed diagonally above), place a ring of Seared blocks (without corners).
ntc2.smeltery.desc4: In this ring, place a &bSmeltery Controller&r and &bSeared Fuel Tank&r. The Smeltery can be up to 65 blocks tall, including the floor. You also need to have a &bSeared Drain&r anywhere in the structure. If the structure is invalid, &6it will show you what parts are wrong&r when you right-click it.
ntc2.smeltery.desc5: If the structure is valid, you will be able to open the Controller's GUI. Give the Fuel Tank fluid fuel (for now, Lava), and any metals you give it will be melted. Molten metals can be pulled from the Drain.
ntc2.smeltery.desc6: &6Some molten metals mix, creating alloys&r. This only happens if you have fuel, so a massive Smeltery with no fuel will function as a safe tank for storing molten metals.
ntc2.smeltery.desc7: The more Seared blocks that make up the Smeltery, the more fuel is used up.
ntc2.smeltery.desc8: Ores melted in the Smeltery are doubled.
ntc2.smelteryio.title: Smeltery IO
ntc2.smelteryio.subtitle: Make the Chute and Duct
ntc2.smelteryio.desc1: The &bChute&r allows you to &6automatically input and output items&r.
ntc2.smelteryio.desc2: The &bDuct&r allows you to &6filter fluid IO&r using buckets or cans.
ntc2.blazing.title: Mob Melting
ntc2.blazing.subtitle: Get a Blazing Blood Bucket
ntc2.blazing.desc1: You can get certain fluids by &6melting mobs&r. Basically, make sure there's any molten metal in the Smeltery, then physically shove a mob into the working area.
ntc2.blazing.desc2: &6Melting a Blaze&r is one of the ways to get &bBlazing Blood&r early on, which is a &6much hotter Smeltery fuel&r.
ntc2.blazing.desc3: Some materials can only be melted with Blazing Blood (&41500°C+&r), and certain Alloys need its heat as well.
ntc2.foundry.title: Foundry
ntc2.foundry.subtitle: Make a Foundry
ntc2.foundry.desc1: The &bFoundry&r is a multiblock, similar to the Smeltery. It is built in the same way, though &6you must include the edges and corners&r.
ntc2.foundry.desc2: The Foundry &6cannot alloy&r and &6stores more fluid&r. Ores smelted will &6make a bit of certain other metals&r, but &6less of that ore's&r. 1 Iron Ore gives 1 ingot and 6 nuggets of iron, as well as 3 nuggets of nickel, for instance.
ntc2.foundry.desc3: There are also Scorched versions of all the other Seared parts, like the Faucet and Casting Table.
ntc2.alloyer.subtitle: Make the Scorched Alloyer
ntc2.alloyer.desc: The &bScorched Alloyer&r will &6alloy the fluids in tanks adjacent to it&r, using fuel from a tank beneath it.
ntc2.foundrybook.subtitle: Make Fantastic Foundry
ntc2.foundrybook.desc: &bFantastic Foundry&r has information on Blazing Blood, the Foundry, and Tier 4 materials.
ntc2.gadgetbook.subtitle: Make Tinker's Gadgetry
ntc2.gadgetbook.desc1: &bTinker's Gadgetry&r has a list of all gadgets added by the mod.
ntc2.gadgetbook.desc2: Melvin seems to be continuing new discoveries of new and useful gadgets.
ntc2.pigback.subtitle: Make a Piggybackpack
ntc2.pigback.desc1: Right-click the &bPiggybackpack&r on a mob to &6carry it on your back&r. You cannot wear a Chestplate while doing this.
ntc2.pigback.desc2: To put the mob down, simply unequip the Piggybackpack from your chestplate slot.
ntc2.pigback.desc3: This is very useful for moving Blazes for &6Blazing Blood&r, though you may want to have fire protection.
ntc2.efln.title: Not For Use Indoors
ntc2.efln.subtitle: Make some EFLN
ntc2.efln.desc2: It does very little damage to mobs, doesn't harm items, and &6drops all the blocks it breaks&r, so it's very useful for mining.
ntc2.efln.desc3: &cDO NOT USE INDOORS!&r To be safe, don't even &ohold&r them in your base. You will 100%% accidentally throw it at your Chest when you try to open it, and you'll have to load a backup.
ntc2.clearglass.title: Clear Glass
ntc2.clearglass.subtitle: Make some Clear Glass
ntc2.clearglass.desc: &bClear Glass&r is completely clear, no borders between blocks! It's used typically in &6Compact Machines&r recipes. So make sure you make lots!
ntc2.slimeboots.title: Slime Boots
ntc2.slimeboots.subtitle: Make Slime Boots
ntc2.slimeboots.desc1: &bSlime Boots&r prevent fall damage, and &6make you bounce&r instead!
ntc2.slimeboots.desc2: They work amazingly when used with the Slime Sling.
ntc2.slimeboots.desc3: Sneak to stop bouncing, though it will give fall damage. All colors are the same.
ntc2.slimesling.title: Slime Slings
ntc2.slimesling.subtitle: Make a Slime Sling
ntc2.slimesling.desc1: &bSlime Slings&r allow you to move in cooler ways, each type being different.
ntc2.slimesling.desc2: Normal Slime will launch you in the direction opposite of where you're looking, when standing and aiming at a block.
ntc2.slimesling.desc3: Skyslime will launch you in the direction you look, but is weaker and works mid-air.
ntc2.slimesling.desc4: Ichor will instead launch the mob you are looking at.
ntc2.slimesling.desc5: Enderslime will teleport you through the wall you are aiming at.
ntc2.cans.subtitle: Make a Can
ntc2.cans.desc2: They &ccannot pick up or pour fluids&r, but they can stack up to 16.
ntc2.tinkerslime.title: Tinker Slimes
ntc2.tinkerslime.subtitle: Learn where to get the new Slimes that spawn naturally
ntc2.tinkerslime.desc1: &bSkyslimes&r can be found in &6floating islands&r around the world.
ntc2.tinkerslime.desc2: &bEnderslimes&r can be found in &6the End&r, naturally.
ntc2.tinkerslime.desc3: &bCoagulated Blood&r technically isn't a slime, but you get it from damaging mobs in the Smeltery.
ntc2.tinkerslime.desc4: &bIchor&r drops from Orange Slimes, which spawn in islands in &6the Nether&r.
ntc2.tinkerslime.desc5: All &bSlimes&r can also be crafted with seeds, with a little effort. Also you will find that slimes are an excellent EMC source.
ntc2.tinkerslimeseeds.title: Slimy Grass Seeds
ntc2.tinkerslimeseeds.subtitle: Learn how to create Slimy Grass
ntc2.tinkerslimeseeds.desc1: First, make some seeds and plant it on dirt by right clicking it with a seed.
ntc2.tinkerslimesaps.title: Slimy Saplings
ntc2.tinkerslimesaps.desc1: Plant these on their respective slime grass types.
ntc2.stringetc.title: Missingno
ntc2.stringetc.subtitle: Learn what a string, integer, double, etc are
ntc2.stringetc.desc1: A &bString&r is just &6any text&r, including letters, numbers, and punctuation.
ntc2.stringetc.desc2: An &bInteger&r is a &6whole number&r, positive or negative. It can only handle numbers between -2,147,483,647 and 2,147,483,647
ntc2.stringetc.desc3: A &bDouble&r is a &6number with a decimal point&r, like 5.0 instead of 5.
ntc2.stringetc.desc4: A &bLong&r is a &6whole number&r; longs can handle much larger values than integers. Its highest possible value is 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.
ntc2.stringetc.desc6: A &bList&r is a &6group of values&r, which can be of any other type, though only one per list.
ntc2.intbook.subtitle: Get "On the Dynamics of Integration"
ntc2.intbook.desc1: &bOn the Dynamics of Integration&r is &eIntegrated Dynamics&r' guide book.
ntc2.intbook.desc2: It has pages for pretty much everything in the mod, teaching concepts, walking through tutorials, and describing the mod on a block-by-block basis.
ntc2.intbook.desc3: Seriously, &6give the tutorial section a read&r. It does a really good job of walking you through the mod.
ntc2.menrilchunk.title: Menril
ntc2.menrilchunk.subtitle: &eEMCable&r. Chop a Menril tree
ntc2.menrilchunk.desc1: &bMenril Saplings&r, while in the void dimension can be grabbed from the &bTransmutation Tablet&r.
ntc2.menrilchunk.desc2: &bMenril trees&r, which spawn rarely everywhere but very common in the &6Meneglin&r biome.
ntc2.menrilchunk.desc3: When chopped, Menril trees drop &bMenril Wood&r, &bMenril Berries&r, and &bCrystalized Menril Chunks&r, all of which are important crafting components.
ntc2.idsqueezer.title: Squeeze it, grab it, squeeze and tug on my integrated flap
ntc2.idsqueezer.subtitle: Make a Squeezer
ntc2.idsqueezer.desc1: Right-click Menril Wood into a &bSqueezer&r to insert it, then jump up and down on top of it to squish it down, producing &6Menril Resin&r.
ntc2.idsqueezer.desc2: The Menril Resin will automatically be output to a fluid container on &6two of its sides&r.
ntc2.idsqueezer.desc3: Give the Squeezer a &6redstone signal&r to reset it.
ntc2.idwrench.subtitle: Make a Wrench
ntc2.idwrench.desc1: The &bWrench&r is a wrench. It does wrench things.
ntc2.idwrench.desc2: Right-clicking a Logic Cable connection will disable that connection. Right-clicking while sneaking will break the part itself.
ntc2.labeller.subtitle: Make a Labeller
ntc2.labeller.desc: You can put any item into the &bLabeller&r's GUI, type something in the text box, then click &6Write&r to rename the item.
ntc2.mechanicalsqueezer.subtitle: Make a Mechanical Squeezer
ntc2.mechanicalsqueezer.desc1: The &bMechanical Squeezer&r &6uses FE&r to convert Menril Wood into Menril Resin, at the same time as producing Crystallized Menril Chunks.
ntc2.mechanicalsqueezer.desc2: In its GUI, you can toggle whether or not it should auto-eject fluids to adjacent tanks.
ntc2.mechanicalsqueezer.desc3: It's also efficient early game crushing. Getting resources more effectively such as flint and gravel.
ntc2.dryingbasin.subtitle: Make a Drying Basin
ntc2.dryingbasin.desc1: The &bDrying Basin&r will dry items/fluids inserted into it. Some recipes may require both items &oand&r fluids to work; see its uses in JEI.
ntc2.dryingbasin.desc2: Its most important use is to &6convert Menril Resin into a Block of Crystallized Menril&r.
ntc2.idfacade.title: Facades
ntc2.idfacade.subtitle: Make a Facade
ntc2.idfacade.desc1: &bFacades&r can hide your Logic Cables, making them look like a different block.
ntc2.idfacade.desc2: Craft a Facade with any block, then right-click it on the Logic Cable to disguise it.
ntc2.mechdrybas.subtitle: Make a Mechanical Drying Basin
ntc2.mechdrybas.desc1: The &bMechanical Drying Basin&r works just like the Drying Basin, but uses FE.
ntc2.mechdrybas.desc2: One of the most important uses in this pack is to get Netherrack early game.
ntc2.logiccable.subtitle: Make Logic Cables
ntc2.logiccable.desc: &bLogic Cables&r are the mod's pipes; they connect network components.
ntc2.monoconn.subtitle: Make a Mono-Directional Connector
ntc2.monoconn.desc1: &bMono-Directional Connectors&r allow you to &6connect sections of a network wirelessly&r.
ntc2.monoconn.desc2: Place two MDCs facing each other (so a straight line from one reaches the other), 512 blocks or less away. They also even work if blocks are in the way.
ntc2.omnicon.subtitle: Make Omni-Directional Connectors
ntc2.omnicon.desc1: &bOmni-Directional Connectors&r, which are crafted in pairs, will connect the networks they are placed on wirelessly. This includes &6across dimensions&r.
ntc2.omnicon.desc2: As the recipe for an ODC gives 2, those 2 are paired together.
ntc2.variablecard.subtitle: Make a Variable Card
ntc2.variablecard.desc1: &bVariable Cards&r are the primary mode of &6logic transport&r. They contain a reference to a certain value with a certain value type.
ntc2.variablecard.desc2: Network components (like a Redstone Reader) have &6Aspects&r (Redstone, Comparator, etc) of specific &6Types&r (Boolean, Integer, etc).
ntc2.variablecard.desc3: For components that read/set variables (like Readers), you can insert a Variable Card next to an Aspect to &6save a reference to that variable&r.
ntc2.variablecard.desc4: Then, you would insert the set Variable Card into something that &ouses&r a variable (say, a Display Panel) and it will do some logic with it.
ntc2.variablecard.desc5: &6An unset Variable Card functions as a Boolean: True variable.&r
ntc2.integratedids.title: Reduce, &mReuse&r, Recycle
ntc2.integratedids.subtitle: ID's little lag problem
ntc2.integratedids.desc1: &eIntegrated Dynamics&r has a bit of a lag problem &6when the Variable ID count gets too high&r. When you reset a Variable or Part by crafting it by itself, it &cmakes a new ID every time&r, and keeps checking for the old one.
ntc2.integratedids.desc2: And by "a bit of lag," I mean &cpotentially world-breaking&r.
ntc2.integratedids.desc3: The majority of users won't notice anything, but if you want to test some setups (creating dozens of new variables and parts), I suggest &6doing it in a creative test world first&r.
ntc2.integratedids.desc4: Make sure your build &oworks&r before implementing it in your survival world. &6Minimize the the amount of Variable and Part IDs.&r
ntc2.integratedids.desc5: As an example: if you take this card
ntc2.integratedids.desc6: and craft it by itself to reset it, then make it into a new variable, it &6gets a new Variable ID&r!
ntc2.integratedids.desc7: However, if you &odon't&r reset it, and just &6reprogram the existing variable&r, it keeps the old ID! The same is true for Parts.
ntc2.displaypanel.subtitle: Make a Display Panel
ntc2.displaypanel.desc1: The &bDisplay Panel&r takes a Variable Card and will display its value.
ntc2.displaypanel.desc2: For instance, if given a Card for the integer value of a redstone signal, the Panel will display the numerical strength of the signal.
ntc2.redstoneio.title: Redstone Signal Transfer
ntc2.redstoneio.subtitle: Learn how a simple Reader/Writer combo works
ntc2.redstoneio.desc1: One of the most simple things you can do with Integrated Dynamics is to &btransfer a redstone signal&r.
ntc2.redstoneio.desc2: At the location you want to input the signal, place a &bRedstone Reader&r.
ntc2.redstoneio.desc3: In the Reader's GUI, find the variable we want (in this situation, &6Aspect: Redstone&r, &6Type: Integer&r), and &6use a Variable Card to get a reference to it&r.
ntc2.redstoneio.desc4: If this Variable Card is inserted into anything on the same network that can accept it, it will try to &6match the variable as it changes&r in the Reader.
ntc2.redstoneio.desc5: Insert the Variable Card into the &6Aspect: Redstone&r, &6Type: Integer&r slot of a &bRedstone Writer&r, and it will output a signal that matches the signal given to the Reader.
ntc2.readers.title: Readers
ntc2.readers.subtitle: Make any Reader
ntc2.readers.desc1: &bReaders&r take information from the world and &6expose them as variables&r.
ntc2.readers.desc2: Different Readers take different information; their &6tooltips&r give short explanations for each.
ntc2.readers.desc3: Each also have some pages in &nOn the Dynamics of Integration&r, if the tooltips aren't informative enough.
ntc2.readers.desc4: &c&nVery important&r: at the top right of every component, you can &6change its settings&r. Most importantly is &6Ticks/Operation&r, aka how many ticks it waits before trying to work.
ntc2.readers.desc5: The mod defaults to 1 (so it checks every tick, aka 20 times a second), but we've changed it to 5 (so it checks 4 times a second). You may want to increase this further to decrease the &clag&r it may cause.
ntc2.writers.title: Writers
ntc2.writers.subtitle: Make any Writer
ntc2.writers.desc1: &bWriters&r take a variable from a &6Variable Card&r and do something with them. There are actually some very things you can do with Writers, like &6say things with the narrator&r,
ntc2.writers.desc2: There are actually fairly few functional Writers. See their tooltips or the book for information on each.
ntc2.writers.desc3: You may expect them to work like Refined Storage's Reader/Writers, but you &ccannot move items, fluids, or energy&r with Integrated Dynamics alone.
ntc2.writers.desc4: That's not to say you can't move items etc at all; the addon &eIntegrated Tunnels&r adds components that do this. We'll go over those later.
ntc2.logprogram.title: Logic Operations
ntc2.logprogram.subtitle: Make a Logic Programmer
ntc2.logprogram.desc1: The &bLogic Programmer&r allows you to take a variable, do some math on it, and turn that into another variable.
ntc2.logprogram.desc2: This can also be used to &6make variables that can't be made with Readers&r, like arbitrary strings or integers.
ntc2.logprogram.desc3: On the left is a list of variable types and operators. Choose one (for now, let's make a string), set what you want it to be, then &6insert a Variable Card&r into the bottom right slot. This will set the Card to the variable you just made.
ntc2.logprogram.desc4: &6Operators&r take existing variables to make new ones. For instance, a &6+&r operator takes two integer variables and adds them, making a third variable.
ntc2.logprogram.desc5: Not all operators are strictly math. The &6name&r operator takes any named object (like an item or integer) and converts it into a string variable.
ntc2.logprogram.desc6: This could be used with the &6contains&r operator to give a positive boolean value if, for example, the item "minecraft:iron_ingot" is turned into the string "Iron Ingot," which is then checked to see if it contains the phrase "Ingot."
ntc2.logprogram.desc7: Operators that depend on variables require that those variables exist in the network. You can put the base variables in the &bVariable Store&r block, which does nothing with the Variable Cards except expose them to the network.
ntc2.proxies.subtitle: Make a Proxy
ntc2.proxies.desc1: The &bProxy&r can have a Variable Card stored in it, and then can have additional Cards bound to it.
ntc2.proxies.desc2: Variable Cards bound to a Proxy will &6always match the output of the Proxie's Card&r, even if it changes. The Proxy must have a Card stored in the top slot to work.
ntc2.proxies.desc3: This can also be used to effectively &6copy Variable Cards&r.
ntc2.delayer.subtitle: Make a Delayer
ntc2.delayer.desc1: The &bDelayer&r can have a Variable Card stored in it, and then can have additional Cards bound to it.
ntc2.delayer.desc2: Variable Cards bound to a Delayer will &6store a List of the previous outputs of the main Variable&r. The Delayer must have a Card stored in the top slot to work.
ntc2.delayer.desc3: In the Delayer's GUI allows you to set how often it checks, as well as how large the list is.
ntc2.delayer.desc4: An &6example&r use-case for this would be to get the average or difference over the most recent values of a variable.
ntc2.materializer.title: Constants
ntc2.materializer.subtitle: Make a Materializer
ntc2.materializer.desc1: The &bMaterializer&r accepts a variable, and then if you insert a second Variable Card, it will turn it into a &6constant of the variable's current value&r.
ntc2.materializer.desc2: For instance, if you put a Block variable in the top, make it so that variable is set to Cobblestone, then insert a Variable Card into the bottom right, it creates a &6Block variable that is always equal to Cobblestone&r.
ntc2.materializer.desc3: This is very useful for comparing values. Instead of doing:
ntc2.integratedtunnels.title: Item Transfer
ntc2.integratedtunnels.subtitle: Make an item transfer system with Integrated Tunnels
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc1: &eIntegrated Tunnels&r is an addon for Integrated Dynamics that gives it the ability to &6import, store, and export items/fluids/energy within a network&r. You &ccannot just move an item from one place to another&r, it has to go into storage at least temporarily.
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc2: To begin with, make the &bItem Interface&r. Place this on an inventory, like a Chest, and imported items will be stored here.
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc3: Next, place an &bItem Importer&r on an inventory that you want to pull from. In it, there are slots for variables that control if it should import all items, import specific items, import only from a specific slot, etc.
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc4: Now, items placed in this inventory should &6extremely quickly&r be moved to the inventory with an Item Interface.
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc5: Place an &bItem Exporter&r on an inventory that you want to push into. Like the importer, it has variables that can control what gets exported.
ntc2.integratedtunnels.desc6: Congrats! You have now automated item transfer! These skills will very easily transfer to fluids and energy, as they all work in the same &6insert, store, export&r method.
ntc2.itwhitelist.title: Whitelists
ntc2.itwhitelist.subtitle: Learn how to whitelist what is moved
ntc2.itwhitelist.desc1: The "Import/Export All Items" booleans are fairly obvious in what they do, but you &oprobably&r won't always want to move &oeverything&r.
ntc2.itwhitelist.desc2: Importers and Exporters have the various variables that allow you to &bspecify what is moved&r.
ntc2.itwhitelist.desc3: For instance, you can put a Variable Card set to Menril Wood (set using the &7Type: Item&r function of a &6Logic Programmer&r) into the &7Export Item&r slot of an Item Exporter, and it will only export Menril Wood.
ntc2.itwhitelist.desc4: Or, you could make a &6List&r of items, or even &6predicate&r (math, basically).
ntc2.itwhitelist.desc5: You could also have an &6Inventory Reader&r point at a Chest, get the &cList: Items&r to get its entire contents and use that, so it will use the items in the Chest as a whitelist.
ntc2.worldints.title: Placing and Breaking
ntc2.worldints.subtitle: Make any World Importer/Exporter
ntc2.worldints.desc1: &bWorld Importers/Exporters&r, as the names suggest, interact with the world instead of inventories.
ntc2.worldints.desc2: World Item, Fluid, Energy, and Block Yada-yadas, in order, &6pick up and drop items&r, &6place and pick up fluids&r, &6discharge and charge dropped items&r, and &6place and mine blocks&r.
ntc2.worldints.desc3: These can have whitelists, so you could automate placing Stone next to a Pure Daisy, then only allow it to break Livingrock.
ntc2.playersim.subtitle: Make a Player Simulator
ntc2.playersim.desc1: The &bPlayer Simulator&r will &6simulate clicking&r, as if it were a player.
ntc2.playersim.desc2: It has variables for clicking with no item or clicking with a random or specific item in the network (via Item Interfaces)
ntc2.playersim.desc3: Every variable have aspects. The most important one here, in my opinion, would be a &9Boolean: Right Click&r. If true, it simulates a right-click. If false, it simlates a left-click, which can punch mobs and break blocks (if &9Continuous Click&r is set to true).
ntc2.itnonitems.title: Non-item tunnels
ntc2.itnonitems.subtitle: Make any non-item tunnel
ntc2.itnonitems.desc: There are also &bInterfaces&r, &bImporters&r, and &bExporters&r for fluid and energy!
ntc2.energybattery.subtitle: Make an Energy Battery
ntc2.energybattery.desc1: If FE is imported into the network, but it doesn't have any valid Energy Interface to store it in, it will be stored in any &bEnergy Battery&r connected to the network.
ntc2.energybattery.desc2: Energy Batteries do not have to be connected with an Interface, they &6automatically connect to adjacent Logic Cables&r.
ntc2.energybattery.desc3: Sneak right-clicking an Energy Battery in your inventory will make it charge your items.
ntc2.storageterminal.subtitle: Make a Storage Terminal
ntc2.storageterminal.desc1: The &bStorage Terminal&r allows access to all stored items and fluids in the network (&6connected by Interfaces&r).
ntc2.storageterminal.desc2: You can use the Storage Terminal like a chest, removing and adding items is almost exactly identical.
ntc2.storageterminal.desc3: For fluids and energy, pick them up like you would an item, then click them on a container in your inventory.
ntc2.storageterminal.desc4: Additionally, there is a tab that has a &63x3 crafting grid&r, allowing you to craft using items in storage.
ntc2.storageterminal.desc5: The Storage Terminal is added by the addon &eIntegrated Terminals&r; it is not there by default.
ntc2.intcrafting.subtitle: Make a Crafting Interface
ntc2.intcrafting.desc1: The &bCrafting Interface&r is the first step to auto-crafting using your network.
ntc2.intcrafting.desc2: Attach the Crafting Interface &6to the machine you want to craft with&r. For regular 3x3 crafting recipes, attach it to a Crafting Table; for smelting recipes, attach it to a Furnace; etc.
ntc2.intcrafting.desc3: Using a &6Logic Programmer&r, click &9Recipe&r and set the crafting recipe you want. For instance, place 8 Oak Planks in the left slots, then place a Chest in the right slots.
ntc2.intcrafting.desc4: Insert this Variable Card into one of the slots in the Crafting Interface, and the network will now have access to that recipe.
ntc2.ictips.title: Crafting Tips
ntc2.ictips.subtitle: Learn some tips for recipe-making
ntc2.ictips.desc1: You can also &6shift-click&r the input slots to change what they accept (so you can set it to use a tag, or if it requires the specific NBT).
ntc2.ictips.desc2: &6Right-click&r a filled slot to increase the amount by 1; &6left-click&r to decrease by 1.
ntc2.craftwriter.subtitle: Make a Crafting Writer
ntc2.craftwriter.desc1: The &bCrafting Writer&r will &6automatically craft things when it isn't available in the system&r.
ntc2.craftwriter.desc2: It can be anywhere in the network, it doesn't have to face any block. There must be a valid recipe in a Crafting Interface for it to work. Each Writer can only make a single thing.
ntc2.craftwriter.desc4: • Craft using a specific recipe, which takes a recipe variable
ntc2.craftwriter.desc5: • Craft a specific item using any recipe, which takes an item variable
ntc2.craftwriter.desc6: • Craft a fluid using any recipe, which takes a fluid variable
ntc2.craftwriter.desc7: • Craft energy using any recipe, which takes an integer variable
ntc2.craftwriter.desc8: By default, it &6crafts only the item is not in the network&r at all. So, it'll craft once, then stop. Enabling &9Ignore Storage Contents&r will make it craft forever.
ntc2.craftjob.subtitle: Make a Crafting Job Terminal
ntc2.craftjob.desc1: The &bCrafting Job Terminal&r has a list of all current crafting jobs in its network.
ntc2.craftjob.desc2: You can click on any crafting job to cancel it.
ntc2.magma.subtitle: Lava into Magma
ntc2.netherrack.subtitle: Magma into Netherrack
ntc2.netherbrick.subtitle: A nether brick in the wall
ntc2.dispenser.subtitle: Output
ntc2.dispenser.desc1: Used to make Output Variable Transformer.
ntc2.collector.subtitle: Input
ntc2.collector.desc1: Used to make Input Variable Transformers.
ntc2.engineersmanual.title: The &bEngineer's Manual&r
ntc2.engineersmanual.subtitle: Get the Engineer's Manual
ntc2.engineersmanual.desc: The &bEngineer's Manual&r is generally the best place for information on Immersive Engineering.
ntc2.steel.title: Steel
ntc2.steel.subtitle: Need.... more.... MORE!!!!
ntc2.steel.desc: One block takes 9 minutes &l&b[real life time]&r. Where as 1 ingot takes 1 minute.
ntc2.iepipe.title: &bFluid Pipes&r
ntc2.iepipe.subtitle: Make Fluid Pipe
ntc2.iepipe.desc1: &bFluid Pipes&r are used to transfer fluids.
ntc2.iepipe.desc2: They do not pull on their own; &6fluids must be pushed into them&r.
ntc2.iepipe.desc3: You can use the &6Engineer's Hammer&r to disable connections. Using &6Scaffolding&r on a Pipe will cover it.
ntc2.iepump.subtitle: Make a Fluid Pump
ntc2.iepump.desc1: The &bFluid Pump&r has two uses: &6collecting in-world fluids&r, and &6quickly extracting from tanks&r.
ntc2.iepump.desc2: To pump in-world fluids, place the Fluid Pump directly &6above the fluid source&r, provide it FE from the top, and give it a redstone signal. You will need to use an &6Engineer's Hammer&r to set which side to output the pumped fluid.
ntc2.iepump.desc3: To extract from tanks, place the Fluid Pump &6directly adjacent to the tank&r, with the side touching it set to input. When given a redstone signal, it will pull fluids out of that tank and push it out of any output sides. This &6does not require FE&r.
ntc2.ieconveyor.subtitle: Make some Conveyor Belts
ntc2.ieconveyor.desc1: &bConveyor Belts&r will &6move entities&r in the direction they are pointed. If aimed at an inventory, it will insert items into it.
ntc2.ieconveyor.desc2: Right-click it with an Engineer's Hammer to turn it
ntc2.ieconveyor.desc3: Conveyor Belts can be dyed by right-clicking, and a redstone signal will disable them.
ntc2.ieotherbelts.title: Unconventional Conveyors
ntc2.ieotherbelts.subtitle: Make the other Conveyor Belts
ntc2.ieotherbelts.desc1: &bExtractor Conveyor Belts&r will &6pull items out of the inventory it is facing&r and put them on the Conveyor Belt. Sneak click with an Engineer's Hammer to set which side to pull from, and click with Wire Cutters to choose how often it pulls.
ntc2.ieotherbelts.desc2: &bDropping Conveyor Belts&r will &6drop items&r, either into the world or into the inventory directly below.
ntc2.ieotherbelts.desc3: &bRedstone Controlled Conveyor Belts&r turn off when given a redstone signal.
ntc2.ieotherbelts.desc4: &bSplitting Conveyor Belts&r will &6alternate between sending things left or right&r.
ntc2.ieotherbelts.desc5: &bVertical Conveyor Belts&r will &6move items up&r, and then onto the block the top one is placed on.
ntc2.iecoveredbelt.title: &bCovered Conveyor Belts&r
ntc2.iecoveredbelt.subtitle: Make a Covered Conveyor Belt
ntc2.iecoveredbelt.desc1: One of the biggest problems with Conveyor Belts is that, if you get too close, you'll pick up the items they are carrying.
ntc2.iecoveredbelt.desc2: &bCovered Conveyor Belts'&r items cannot be picked up, which solves that problem.
ntc2.iecoveredbelt.desc3: &6Almost every Belt type has a Covered version.&r
ntc2.ierouter.subtitle: Make an Item Router
ntc2.ierouter.desc1: The &bItem Router&r will send items input into the direction that you set.
ntc2.ierouter.desc2: Each side has a color. In the GUI, you can set a whitelist of 8 items per color-coded side, and those items will be output through that side.
ntc2.ierouter.desc3: You can also toggle &6Tag&r, &6NBT&r, and &6Fuzzy Filters&r per side.
ntc2.engineershammer.title: &bEngineer's Hammer&r
ntc2.engineershammer.subtitle: Make an Engineer's Hammer
ntc2.engineershammer.desc1: The &bEngineer's Hammer&r is arguably the most important tool in Immersive Engineering. It is required to form multiblocks and configure some other specific machines.
ntc2.engineershammer.desc2: You can also use it to &6crush ores and chunks&r.
ntc2.iecokeoven.title: The &bCoke Oven&r
ntc2.iecokeoven.subtitle: Construct a Coke Oven
ntc2.iecokeoven.desc1: The &bCoke Oven&r is the only way to get &6Coal Coke&r and &6Creosote Oil&r early game.
ntc2.iecokeoven.desc2: Make a &63x3x3 cube of Coke Bricks&r, then right-click the center of any face with an Engineer's Hammer to form it.
ntc2.iecokeoven.task:
Look at a completed Coke Oven

27x Coke Bricks
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.title: The &bCrude Blast Furnace&r
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.subtitle: Construct a Crude Blast Furnace
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.desc1: The &bCrude Blast Furnace&r allows you to &6burn Iron with Coal Coke or Charcoal to get Steel&r.
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.desc2: Like the Coke Oven, make a 3x3x3 cube of Blast Bricks then click with an Engineer's Hammer to form it.
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.desc3: The Crude Blast Furnace &ccannot be automated&r.
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.desc4: A block of Iron takes 10800 ticks to complete. An Ingot of Iron takes 1200 ticks to complete. A block of Coal Coke provides 12000 ticks of burn time, thus being able to smelt 10 Iron Ingots. One Coal Coke provides 1200 ticks of burn time, thus being able to smelt one Iron Ingot.
ntc2.ieblastfurnace.task:
Look at a completed Blast Furnace

27x Blast Bricks
ntc2.improvedblastfurnace.title: The &bImproved Blast Furnace&r
ntc2.improvedblastfurnace.subtitle: Construct the Improved Blast Furnace
ntc2.improvedblastfurnace.desc1: The &bImproved Blast Furnace&r works the same as a Crude Blast Furnace, except &6it can be automated&r. Inputs must be entered through the top, Steel is output through the front, and Slag is output through the back.
ntc2.improvedblastfurnace.desc2: Again, &6click an Engineer's Hammer on the center of any face&r to form it.
ntc2.improvedblastfurnace.task:
Look at a completed Improved Blast Furnace

27x Reinforced Blast Bricks
1x Hopper
ntc2.blastfurnacepreheaters.title: &bBlast Furnace Preheaters&r
ntc2.blastfurnacepreheaters.subtitle: Make a pair of Blast Furnace Preheaters
ntc2.blastfurnacepreheaters.desc: &bBlast Furnace Preheaters&r can be placed on either side of the Improved Blast Furnace to &6speed them up&r, when provided FE through their tops.
ntc2.iewindmill.title: The &bWind Mill&r
ntc2.iewindmill.subtitle: Set up a Wind Mill
ntc2.iewindmill.desc1: The &bWind Mill&r, when placed on a &bKinetic Dynamo&r, will generate FE based on the current wind speed (which itself is based on weather, elevation, and certain other factors).
ntc2.iewindmill.desc2: You can install up to 8 &bWindmill Sails&r to increase this amount.
ntc2.iewindmill.desc3: When placed above y=200, in a thunder storm, with 8 Windmill Sails, the Wind Mill will generate &6100 FE/t maximum&r.
ntc2.waterwheel.subtitle: The &bWater Wheel&r
ntc2.waterwheel.desc1: The &bWater Wheel&r, when placed on a &bKinetic Dynamo&r, will generate FE when the edges are pushed by flowing Water.
ntc2.waterwheel.desc2: &6The more flowing water it is touching, the more FE/t it makes (at a maximum of 28FE/t per wheel).&r It generates at that speed infinitely, unless the water is removed or changed.
ntc2.waterwheel.desc3: You can have &6up to three Water Wheels per Kinetic Dynamo&r, simply by placing them on the same axis.
ntc2.waterwheel.desc4: This is the optimal setup, using 3 Wheels with water sources where each arrow is. You will need to constantly pump water over the wheel because water physics is in this pack.
ntc2.waterwheel.desc5: Note, this only makes 88 FE/t, so it's not &osuper&r useful in this pack.
ntc2.iecables.title: Immersive Engineering's Wires
ntc2.iecables.subtitle: Set up some Wires
ntc2.iecables.desc1: Immersive Engineering's Wires are unique. Instead of placing down a block for every part of the path, you only place connections.
ntc2.iecables.desc2: &bWire Connectors&r are placed on machines where you want to &6input or extract FE&r from. They can &conly connect to one other thing&r.
ntc2.iecables.desc3: &bWire Relays&r are used to &6connect Wire Connectors&r. All your Connectors should connect to a Relay, which connects to a network of other Relays that eventually connects to a Connector on a power source.
ntc2.iecables.desc4: &bWire Coils&r are clicked on two parts (Connectors/Relays) to connect them. They have a maximum range and cannot go through blocks.
ntc2.iecables.desc5: Wires, Connectors, and Relays come in three tiers, &6LV&r, &6MV&r, and &6HV&r. Higher tiers can move more FE/t (&62,048&r, &68,192&r, and &632,768&r respectively). If more FE than it can handle tries to flow through, that wire will burn up.
ntc2.iecables.desc6: Connectors and Relays &6only work with Wires of the same voltage&r. &cUninsulated Wires will damage anything that touches them.&r Note that there are no Insulated HV Wire Coils.
ntc2.iewirecutters.title: &bEngineer's Wire Cutters&r
ntc2.iewirecutters.subtitle: Make Engineer's Wire Cutters
ntc2.iewirecutters.desc: &bEngineer's Wire Cutters&r will remove all Wire Coils from a Connector/Relay when used on it.
ntc2.ietransformers.title: &bTransformers&r
ntc2.ietransformers.subtitle: Make a Transformer
ntc2.ietransformers.desc1: &bTransformers&r allow you to &6convert between two voltages&r. This allows you to, for instance, use LV Wires for each generator, then group them all together into a single MV Wire that can carry their combined FE/t.
ntc2.ietransformers.desc2: The regular Transformer converts between LV and MV. The &bHV Transformer&r converts between MV and HV.
ntc2.breakerswitch.title: &bBreaker Switch&r
ntc2.breakerswitch.subtitle: Make a Breaker Switch
ntc2.breakerswitch.desc: A &bBreaker Switch&r can have wires connected to either side, and &6will only allow power through them when it is activated&r.
ntc2.iecapacitors.title: &bCapacitors&r
ntc2.iecapacitors.subtitle: Make a Capacitor
ntc2.iecapacitors.desc1: &bCapacitors&r store FE, and have multiple tiers. In order, they store &6100,000FE&r, &61,000,000FE&r, and &64,000,000FE&r.
ntc2.iecapacitors.desc2: Capacitors have no GUI. To set which sides are input or output, &6use an Engineer's Hammer on them&r. Blue=in, orange=out.
ntc2.engineersworkbench.subtitle: Make an Engineer's Workbench
ntc2.engineersworkbench.desc1: The &bEngineer's Workbenches&r offer exclusive crafting recipes, set by the &bEngineer's Blueprint&r inserted into them.
ntc2.engineersworkbench.desc2: Insert the Blueprint, then hover over one of the items on the right and it will say which items and their amounts that you need. Once those requirements are met, you can pull the item out of the right slots.
ntc2.engineersworkbench.desc3: The Blueprints specified in this quest &6can be crafted&r, however there are two others that you can only get by &6trading with a Villager&r.
ntc2.engineersworkbench.desc4: Certain items, like the &6Revolver&r and the &6Mining Drill&r can be upgraded in the Workbench.
ntc2.ieminingdrill.title: The &bMining Drill&r
ntc2.ieminingdrill.subtitle: Make a Mining Drill
ntc2.ieminingdrill.desc1: The &bMining Drill&r is a modular tool that can &6dig through all Dirt and Stone type blocks&r, with the mining level based on the &bDrill Head&r.
ntc2.ieminingdrill.desc2: To install a Drill Head, put the Drill in the left slot of an Engineer's Workbench, and then put the Head in the top center slot.
ntc2.ieminingdrill.desc3: The Mining Drill is &6powered by Biodiesel&r, not FE.
ntc2.ieminingdrill.desc4: The mining area is set by the Drill Head you use. Sneaking will make you mine a single block at a time.
ntc2.miningdrillupgrades.title: Drill Upgrades
ntc2.miningdrillupgrades.subtitle: Make any Mining Drill Upgrade
ntc2.miningdrillupgrades.desc1: Up to 3 &bMining Drill upgrades&r can be installed on a Mining Drill by putting it in the left slot of an Engineer's Workbench and upgrades in the center slots.
ntc2.miningdrillupgrades.desc2: Each upgrade's &6tooltip&r explains what it does.
ntc2.buzzsaw.subtitle: Make a Buzzsaw
ntc2.buzzsaw.desc1: The &bBuzzsaw&r is a modular tool that can &6dig through all plant blocks&r quickly.
ntc2.buzzsaw.desc2: To work, you must install a &bSawblade&r in the Engineer's Workbench. You can use a &bRockcutter Blade&r instead, which makes it work as a &6Silk Touch Pickaxe&r rather than an axe.
ntc2.buzzsaw.desc3: Like the Mining Drill, the Buzzsaw is &6powered by Biodiesel&r, not FE.
ntc2.buzzsawupgrades.title: Buzzsaw Upgrades
ntc2.buzzsawupgrades.subtitle: Make any Buzzsaw Upgrade
ntc2.buzzsawupgrades.desc1: Up to 2 &bBuzzsaw Upgrades&r can be installed on a buzzsaw in the Engineer's Workbench.
ntc2.buzzsawupgrades.desc2: Each upgrade's &6tooltip&r explains what it does.
ntc2.ierevolver.title: RTBA
ntc2.ierevolver.subtitle: Make a Revolver
ntc2.ierevolver.desc1: The &bRevolver&r is a ranged weapon that can accept several types of ammo. To insert the ammo, sneak right-click it and manually &6insert up to 8 Cartridges&r. Right-click to fire the top Cartridge, and it will rotate all slots counterclockwise.
ntc2.ierevolver.desc2: A &6Speedloader&r can also be filled with Cartridges, and it will automatically reload the Revolver if fired while empty.
ntc2.ierevolver.desc3: There are &611 types of Cartridge&r, each having something unique about it. &6Read the Engineer's Manual&r page for them for an explanation for each.
ntc2.ierevolver.desc4: For reference, &6a Casull Cartridge deals 7.5 hearts of damage&r.
ntc2.ierevolverupgrades.title: &bRevolver upgrades&r
ntc2.ierevolverupgrades.subtitle: Make a Revolver upgrade
ntc2.ierevolverupgrades.desc1: Up to 2 &bRevolver upgrades&r can be installed on a Revolver by putting the Revolver in the left slot of an Engineer's Workbench and upgrades in the center slots.
ntc2.ierevolverupgrades.desc2: Each upgrade's &6tooltip&r explains what it does.
ntc2.iechemthrower.title: The &bChemical Thrower&r
ntc2.iechemthrower.subtitle: Make a Chemical Thrower
ntc2.iechemthrower.desc1: The &bChemical Thrower&r will &6shoot whatever fluid/gas it has&r in its internal tank. If that fluid is flammable, you can sneak right-click to toggle lighting it on fire.
ntc2.iechemthrower.desc2: There's no in-game list of what each fluid does, but it's pretty self-evident. Lava makes fires, Water puts out fires, Oils/Diesels can be lit on fire, etc.
ntc2.chemthrowerupgrades.title: Chemical Thrower Upgrades
ntc2.chemthrowerupgrades.subtitle: Make a Chemical Thrower upgrade
ntc2.chemthrowerupgrades.desc1: Up to 2 &bChemical Thrower upgrades&r can be installed on a Chemical Thrower by putting the Thrower in the left slot of an Engineer's Workbench and upgrades in the center slots.
ntc2.chemthrowerupgrades.desc2: Each upgrade's &6tooltip&r explains what it does.
ntc2.ierailgun.title: The &bRailgun&r
ntc2.ierailgun.subtitle: Make a Railgun
ntc2.ierailgun.desc1: The &bRailgun&r uses a large amount of FE to &6shoot Aluminum/Iron/Steel Rods&r, or &6Graphite Electrodes&r. To shoot, hold right-click and then release when the charger reaches 99.
ntc2.ierailgun.desc2: The higher tiers of ammo deal more damage (&6in same order as above: 13, 15, 18, and 24 points&r).
ntc2.ierailgun.desc3: The Railgun uses a &olot&r of FE, so &6it's suggested that you have a way to charge it on the go&r.
ntc2.railgunups.title: Railgun Upgrades
ntc2.railgunups.subtitle: Make a Railgun upgrade
ntc2.railgunups.desc1: Up to 2 &bRailgun upgrades&r can be installed on a Railgun by putting it in the left slot of an Engineer's Workbench and upgrades in the center slots.
ntc2.railgunups.desc2: Each upgrade's &6tooltip&r explains what it does.
ntc2.iechargingstation.subtitle: Make a Charging Station
ntc2.iechargingstation.desc1: The &bCharging Station&r will &6charge any item&r you insert into it with FE. It has &6no GUI&r, so just click it to insert or remove an item.
ntc2.iechargingstation.desc2: &6FE can only be inserted via the bottom or the back sides.&r
ntc2.iegardencloche.title: OP Farm
ntc2.iegardencloche.subtitle: Make a Garden Cloche
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc1: The &bGarden Cloche&r will &6grow and harvest crops&r within itself. It's very fast and honestly weirdly cheap, for how good it is.
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc2: It requires a &6steady supply of Water and FE&r. You can also give it fertilizer in the bottom left slot.
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc3: Insert a seed into the top center slot, and its required soil underneath. &6Pretty much every crop is compatible&r!
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc4: The harvested crop will be pushed out of the &6middle-front&r.
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc5: Water and fertilizer can be input through the &6bottom&r, &6bottom-front&r, or &6bottom-back&r.
ntc2.iegardencloche.desc6: FE can be input through the &6top&r, &6bottom-left&r, or &6bottom-right&r.
ntc2.iemetalpress.title: The &bMetal Press&r
ntc2.iemetalpress.subtitle: Construct a Metal Press
ntc2.iemetalpress.desc1: The &bMetal Press&r. It gives &6cheaper recipes for Plates, Gears, Rods, etc&r, using &bMetal Press Molds&r.
ntc2.iemetalpress.desc2: Insert items, give it the correct Mold, and then it will use FE (which is entered from the top) to press the item according to the Mold. Items will be output at the end, into an inventory or Conveyor Belt.
ntc2.iemetalpress.desc3: You &ccannot speed it up&r, it works at one speed only.
ntc2.iemetalpress.task:
Look at a completed Metal Press

1x Piston
2x Steel Scaffolding
1x Redstone Engineering Block
1x Heavy Engineering Block
2x Conveyor Belt
ntc2.ieassembler.title: Autocrafting
ntc2.ieassembler.subtitle: Construct an Assembler
ntc2.ieassembler.desc1: The &bAssembler&r can &6automatically craft&r up to three recipes using items and fluids inserted into it.
ntc2.ieassembler.desc2: The result of the first recipe can be used as an ingredient in the second recipe, and so on. The final non-empty recipe result will be &6output from the back&r.
ntc2.ieassembler.desc3: If a recipe would use fluids (say, Treated Wood), it &6can use the tanks instead of a bucket item&r.
ntc2.ieassembler.desc4: &6Power&r can enter the top; &6items&r, the front center; &6fluids&r, the front bottom.
ntc2.ieassembler.task:
Look at a completed Assembler

ntc2.ieindussqueeze.title: Industrial Squeezer
ntc2.ieindussqueeze.subtitle: Construct an Industrial Squeezer
ntc2.ieindussqueeze.desc: The &bIndustrial Squeezer&r presses the juices out of organic material, like seeds.
ntc2.ieindussqueeze.task:
Look at a completed Squeezer

ntc2.iearcfurnace.title: Arc Furnace
ntc2.iearcfurnace.subtitle: Construct an Arc Furnace
ntc2.iearcfurnace.desc1: The &bArc Furnace&r &6doubles ores and smelts alloys&r, producing Slag as a byproduct.
ntc2.iearcfurnace.desc2: To function, the Arc Furnace &6requires 3 Graphite Electrodes&r in the top slots. These will wear down as the Arc Furnace runs, and must be replaced when broken.
ntc2.iearcfurnace.desc3: The item to be worked goes in the left; the Arc Furnace will &6smelt all slots at the same time&r. In the case of alloying, the main part goes in the left and the secondary ingredients go on the right.
ntc2.iearcfurnace.desc4: Items are inserted in the top and pulled out of the Cauldron; Power is inserted in the three slots in the back; Slag is pulled out of the face under the power slots.
ntc2.iearcfurnace.task:
Look at a completed Arc Furnace

ntc2.iesilo.title: Items &bSilos&r
ntc2.iesilo.subtitle: Construct a Silo
ntc2.iesilo.desc1: A &bSilo&r can &6hold 41,472 of a single item&r (which is 648 stacks, or 24 chests' worth).
ntc2.iesilo.desc2: Items must be input through the top, and extracted from the bottom. Giving the bottom block a redstone signal will make it auto-output.
ntc2.iesilo.task:
Look at a completed Silo

04x Treated Wood Fence
50x Iron Sheetmetal
ntc2.iecrusher.title: The &bCrusher&r
ntc2.iecrusher.subtitle: Construct a Crusher
ntc2.iecrusher.desc1: The &bCrusher&r will &6double ores, grind blocks, and kill mobs&r.
ntc2.iecrusher.desc2: One of the best ways mid game to get tons of &bPotassium Nitrate&r and &bSulfur&r.
ntc2.iecrusher.task:
Look at a completed Crusher

ntc2.ieindusferment.title: Industrial Fermenter
ntc2.ieindusferment.subtitle: Construct an Industrial Fermenter
ntc2.ieindusferment.desc: The &bFermenter&r is used to convert certain plants into &6Ethanol&r.
ntc2.ieindusferment.task:
Look at a completed Industrial Fermenter

ntc2.iemixer.title: The &bMixer&r
ntc2.iemixer.subtitle: Construct a Mixer
ntc2.iemixer.desc1: The &bMixer&r combines items and fluids to &6create new fluids&r.
ntc2.iemixer.desc2: You can use this to make &6potions&r.
ntc2.iemixer.task:
Look at a completed Mixer

ntc2.iecoresample.title: The &bCore Sample Drill&r
ntc2.iecoresample.subtitle: Make a Core Sample Drill
ntc2.iecoresample.desc1: The &bCore Sample Drill&r, once placed and powered, can be right-clicked to get a &6Core Sample&r.
ntc2.iecoresample.desc2: Core Samples will say what mineral/fluid deposit is in that chunk, which is important information for the Excavator and Pumpjack.
ntc2.ieexcavator.title: Excavator
ntc2.ieexcavator.subtitle: Construct an Excavator
ntc2.ieexcavator.desc1: The &bExcavator&r uses a large amount of FE/t to &6pull ores from its chunk's mineral deposit&r.
ntc2.ieexcavator.desc2: This allows you to get a rather large amount of ores, if the chunk has a mineral deposit.
ntc2.ieexcavator.task:
Look at a completed Excavator

ntc2.ippumpjack.title: Black Gold
ntc2.ippumpjack.subtitle: Get some Crude Oil
ntc2.ippumpjack.desc1: &eImmersive Petroleum&r is an addon for Immersive Engineering that is based around &bOil&r.
ntc2.ippumpjack.desc2: It adds the &bPumpjack&r, which uses FE to &6pull fluids from its chunk's fluid deposit&r.
ntc2.ippumpjack.desc3: The mod &eThermal&r, however, adds oil sands that generate naturally which you can extract Crude Oil. Oil sand is also awarded in the quest Thermal: Oil sands. This quest will complete once you get Oil from either source.
ntc2.ipdisttower.title: Distillation Tower
ntc2.ipdisttower.subtitle: Construct a Distillation Tower
ntc2.ipdisttower.desc1: The &bDistillation Tower&r will use FE to &6convert Oil into Gasoline, Diesel, and Lubricant&r. It also produces &6Bitumen&r, which is automatically ejected out the back.
ntc2.ipdisttower.desc2: The Distillation Tower is the largest multiblock, so you should probably &6use the Projector&r.
ntc2.ipdisttower.desc3: Diesel can power the &6Diesel Generator&r; Gasoline can power the &6Motorboat&r and &6Portable Generator&r.
ntc2.ipdisttower.task:
Look at a completed Distillation Tower

ntc2.iplubecan.subtitle: Make a Lubricant Can
ntc2.iplubecan.desc: A full &bLubricant Can&r can be &6clicked on a Pumpjack, Excavator, or Crusher to speed them up&r.
ntc2.ipautolube.subtitle: Make an Automated Lubricator
ntc2.ipautolube.desc1: An &bAutomatic Lubricator&r can be &6placed adjacent to a Pumpjack, Excavator, or Crusher to speed them up&r while it has a supply of Lubricant.
ntc2.ipautolube.desc2: Hold the Automatic Lubricator to see where exactly you need to place it for it to work.
ntc2.iebottlingmachine.title: The &bBottling Machine&r
ntc2.iebottlingmachine.subtitle: Construct a Bottling Machine
ntc2.iebottlingmachine.desc: The &bBottling Machine&r will &6fill a fluid container with a fluid&r.
ntc2.iebottlingmachine.task:
Look at a completed Bottling Machine

ntc2.ietank.title: Not-Too-Portable Tank
ntc2.ietank.subtitle: Construct a Fluid Tank
ntc2.ietank.desc1: The &bFluid Tank&r can &6store 512 buckets&r of a single fluid. You can right-click a Bucket on it to insert or extract fluid.
ntc2.ietank.desc2: Fluids can be input through the top, and extracted from the bottom. Giving the bottom block a redstone signal will make it auto-output.
ntc2.ietank.task:
Look at a completed Fluid Tank

ntc2.ieautoworkbench.desc2: Insert an Engineer's Blueprint, and choose which item you want to autocraft. When it has the items required (and power, obviously), it will craft and output that item.

ntc2.projector.title: The &bProjector&r
ntc2.projector.subtitle: Make a Projector
ntc2.projector.desc1: The &bProjector&r is a very useful item that &6shows you where to place blocks to form multiblocks&r.
ntc2.projector.desc2: You can choose which multiblock in the Projector's GUI. You can mirror it and rotate it to face any direction.
ntc2.projector.desc3: Holding the Projector will show you a hologram of it. Scroll while sneaking to rotate the hologram. Right-click to &6anchor&r the hologram, keeping it where it is as long as the Projector is in your hotbar.
ntc2.projector.desc4: Sneak right-click the Projector to &6un-anchor&r the hologram.
ntc2.thermalwrench.subtitle: The &bwrench&r of &6wrenches&r
ntc2.thermalpedia.subtitle: The good book
ntc2.thermalframe.subtitle: Requires some compaction
ntc2.thermalarboreal.subtitle: One of the few ways to passively get rubber early game
ntc2.induct.subtitle: Needed to make Fluix Crystals
ntc2.induct.desc1: Initially, there are other ways to produce Fluix Crystals; This remains the only way to make them early game.

ntc2.prodbees.subtitle: About &d3X&r more effective than crops when using &bThermal Centrifuge&r
ntc2.prodbees.book.title: Big Book of Bees
ntc2.prodbees.book.subtitle: Seriously. Read this.
ntc2.prodbees.babee.subtitle: An Egg and some Gene Samples make a Bee Egg
ntc2.prodbees.treat.subtitle: Used to make Gene Samples for breeding
ntc2.prodbees.sieving.subtitle: Requires you to Sieve the coresponding block to get Gene Samples
ntc2.prodbees.harvest.title: Harvest Honeycomb
ntc2.prodbees.harvest.desc1: To harvest honeycomb, the player uses shears on the nest or hive, causing it to drop three honeycomb items.
ntc2.prodbees.harvest.desc2: Can be used to remove stingers.
ntc2.prodbees.hive.subtitle: A regular vanilla beehive
ntc2.prodbees.advhive.subtitle: A beehive with a GUI!
ntc2.prodbees.frame.subtitle: Can be used instead of Honeycombs
ntc2.prodbees.bottle.title: Harvest Honey
ntc2.prodbees.bottle.desc1: To harvest honey, the player uses a glass bottle on the nest or hive; the bottle then becomes a honey bottle.
ntc2.prodbees.fabric.subtitle: If you don't want to go through all that trouble of a fire and smoke, make a beekeeper outfit
ntc2.prodbees.fabric.desc1: Harvesting from a beehive or bee nest causes any bees inside it to become aggravated toward the player, unless there is a fire directly beneath it.
ntc2.projecte.power1.subtitle: Use the Randomizer on the Philosopher's Stone to create a Blaze and kill it
ntc2.projecte.power1.desc1: Default is 'R' key; Requires fuel to use such as Coal or ProjectE fuels.
ntc2.projecte.portal1.subtitle: To the Overworld!
ntc2.projecte.portal2.subtitle: There's no place like home!
ntc2.projecte.philstone.title: Philosopher's Stone
ntc2.projecte.philstone.subtitle: The Philosopher's Stone is both a tool and a crafting component added by ProjectE
ntc2.projecte.philstone.desc1: The fabled alchemical catalyst that allows the transmutation of base metals into gold, the Philosopher's Stone is arguably the foundation of ProjectE. There are three basic uses. Firstly, as a component in the construction of items like the Transmutation Table. Secondly, as a transmutation tool, for example turning iron into gold or vice versa. Finally, as a portable crafting table, capable of smelting items.
ntc2.projecte.philstone.desc2: As the Philosopher's Stone is used in such a large number of recipes, the use of a recipe manager such as JEI or NEI is strongly recommended.
ntc2.projecte.darkmatter.desc1: The Dark Matter is an component added by ProjectE. It is used to craft Dark Matter tools and armors and is used as a component to create Red Matter.
ntc2.projecte.redmatter.desc1: Red Matter is a component added by ProjectE. As an item with a high EMC value, it is suitable to be used as a template in an Energy Condenser to store EMC. As a crafting component, Red Matter is used only in the crafting of high-end machines, tools, armor and accessories.
ntc2.projecte.dmfurnace.desc1: The Dark Matter Furnace is a Furnace that can be powered using EMC energy from adjacent machines in addition to solid fuels. It operates very quickly, smelting two items per second. It has two 8-slot inventories for input and output, a slot for fuel input and two buffer slots.
ntc2.projecte.dmfurnace.desc2: The mod official documentation states that it doubles output however in testing, the bonus appears variable. Tests with eleven stacks of Iron Ore and eleven pieces of Alchemical Coal. The outputs varied from 96-106 Iron Ingots per ore stack. Overall the average was 98 ingots per stack of ore, about a 65% bonus.
ntc2.projecte.rmfurnace.desc1: The Red Matter Furnace is a Furnace that can be powered using EMC energy from adjacent machines in addition to solid fuels. It operates extremely quickly, smelting about 6.5 items per second. The GUI is identical to that of the Dark Matter Furnace, having two 8-slot inventories for input and output, a slot for fuel input and two buffer slots. The Red Matter Furnace produces two ingots for each piece of ore.
ntc2.projecte.alchemicalchest.desc1: The Alchemical Chest is a large chest, capable of holding 104 stacks of items (compared to a vanilla double-chest's 72 stacks). In addition, the chest can be upgraded with some utility items that perform special effects. The Black Hole Band will collect items dropped nearby, the Gem of Eternal Density will compress the contents into items of higher EMC value, and the Talisman of Repair will slowly repair items contained within.
ntc2.projecte.alchemicalchest.desc2: It is also used as a crafting component in the creation of Alchemical Bags and the Energy Condenser.
ntc2.projecte.energycondenser.desc1: The Energy Condenser performs three functions.
ntc2.projecte.energycondenser.desc2: Any items placed in the inventory will be destroyed and converted to EMC which is then stored in the internal buffer.
ntc2.projecte.energycondenser.desc3: It receives EMC energy from an adjacent Energy Collector or Anti-Matter Relay.
ntc2.projecte.energycondenser.desc4: Using EMC energy from the internal buffer, it creates items of the type specified.
ntc2.projecte.energycondenser.desc5: The GUI contains an energy bar, a single slot used to specify the item to produce, and a 91-slot inventory to hold the output. As the Energy Condenser receives energy, the energy bar rises. When it reaches 100%, a single item of the type specified is created and placed in the inventory.
ntc2.projecte.energycondensermk2.desc1: The Energy Condenser MK2 is an upgraded version of the Energy Condenser. In addition to being substantially faster than the Energy Condenser, the MK2 also has a separate inventory for output. This separate inventory lets hoppers put items into the Condenser.
ntc2.projecte.energycollectormk1.desc1: It passively generates 4 EMC every 1 second up to a maximum of 10,000 EMC depending on the highest light level. When placed adjacent to an Energy Condenser MK1, Energy Condenser MK2, Anti-Matter Relay MK1, Anti-Matter Relay MK2 or Anti-Matter Relay MK3 it will transfer the EMC into that machine.
ntc2.projecte.energycollectormk2.desc1: It will generate a passive maximum of 12 EMC per second up to a maximum of 30,000 EMC at a light level of 15. When placed adjacent to an Energy Condenser, Energy Condenser MK2, Energy Condenser MK3, Anti-Matter Relay MK2 or Anti-Matter Relay MK1, it will transfer the EMC into that machine.
ntc2.projecte.energycollectormk3.desc1: In strong lighting, or if placed in the nether, it will generate a passive 40 EMC per second up to a maximum of 60,000 EMC. When placed adjacent to a Energy Condenser MK1, Energy Condenser MK2, Energy Condenser MK3, Anti-Matter Relay MK1, Anti-Matter Relay MK2, or Anti-Matter Relay MK3, it will transfer the EMC into that machine.
ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk1.desc1: This machine serves two functions. Firstly, any item placed into its inventory will be converted into EMC. Secondly, it transfers energy from Energy Collectors to Energy Condensers. When transferring, it gives a small, 1 EMC per second bonus. It is also used to charge the Klein Star series with EMC.
ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk1.desc2: It can transfer up to 64 EMC/s and can store up to 100,000 EMC.
