ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk2.desc1: Any item placed into its inventory will be converted into EMC. It transfers energy from Energy Collectors to Energy Condensers. When transferring, it gives a 3 EMC per second bonus. It is also used to charge the Klein Star series with EMC.
ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk2.desc2: It can transfer up to 192 EMC/s and can store up to 1,000,000 EMC.
ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk3.desc1: Any item placed into its inventory will be converted into EMC and will transfer energy from Energy Collectors to Energy Condensers. When transferring, it gives a 10 EMC per second bonus. It will charge any of the Klein Star series with EMC.
ntc2.projecte.antimatterrelaymk3.desc2: It can transfer up to 640 EMC/s and can store up to 10,000,000 EMC.
ntc2.projecte.alchemicalcoal.desc1: &bAlchemical Coal&r: It burns four times as long as regular Coal and is able to smelt 32 items. Alchemical Coal is used in the production of Mobius Fuel.
ntc2.projecte.mobiusfuel.desc1: &bMobius Fuel&r: It burns sixteen times as long as regular coal and is able to smelt 128 items.
ntc2.projecte.aeternalisfuel.desc1: &bAeternalis Fuel&r: By combining 4 pieces of Mobius Fuel with a Philosopher's Stone, a new fuel is created. Aeternalis Fuel burns four times as long as Mobius Fuel and is able to smelt 512 items.
ntc2.projecte.repairtal.desc1: When placed in the belt slot or in the player's inventory it will regenerate all damaged tools at a rate of 1 durability point per second. Placing it in an Alchemical Bag will restore the durability of all tools also stored inside.
ntc2.projecte.intertorch.desc1: When placed, the Interdiction Torch casts a light level of 15 and creates a small, invisible, protective bubble that covers an 8-block radius. Hostile mobs and projectiles are physically repelled by the bubble.
ntc2.projecte.dmpedestal.desc1: The Dark Matter Pedestal can hold a ProjectE utility item, such as the Black Hole Band, and asymmetrically project the effect in a 10x10x10 area centered around the pedestal's upper southeast corner. Valid items include those listed in the Baubles and Misc Utilities sections from the navigation bar at the bottom of this article.
ntc2.projecte.dmpedestal.desc2: An item can be placed on the pedestal by right-clicking it. Right-clicking it with an empty hand toggles the effects on or off. When the pedestal is active, small flames appear around the base. Items placed on the Dark Matter Pedestal can be removed by left-clicking on the Pedestal.
ntc2.projecte.stars.desc1: Klein Stars can be charged by being placed in a Transmutation Table and being feed in items, or by being placed in the charging slot of an Energy Collector or Anti-Matter Relay. Klein Stars are discharged by being placed them in the discharging slot of an Anti-Matter Relay.
ntc2.projecte.ein.desc1: Klein Star Ein holds up to 50,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of Klein Star Zwei.
ntc2.projecte.zwei.desc1: Klein Star Zwei holds up to 200,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of Klein Star Drei.
ntc2.projecte.drei.desc1: Klein Star Drei holds up to 800,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of Klein Star Vier.
ntc2.projecte.vier.desc1: Klein Star Vier holds up to 3,200,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of the Klein Star Sphere.
ntc2.projecte.sphere.desc1: Klein Star Sphere holds up to 12,800,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of Klein Star Omega.
ntc2.projecte.omega.desc1: Klein Star Omega holds up to 51,200,000 EMC and is also used in the crafting of top-tier armor.
ntc2.projecte.dmhelm.desc1: In addition to providing physical protection similar to the Diamond Helmet, it reduces damage taken by 80%%. Dark Matter Armor has no durability thus cannot be damage while being worn. The Dark Matter Helmet is also used in the crafting of the Red Matter Helmet.
ntc2.projecte.dmchest.desc1: In addition to providing physical protection similar to the Diamond Chestplate, it reduces damage taken by 80%%. Dark Matter Armor has no durability thus cannot be damage while being worn. The Dark Matter Chestplate is also used in the crafting of the Red Matter Chestplate.
ntc2.projecte.dmlegs.desc1: In addition to providing physical protection similar to the Diamond Leggings, they reduce damage taken by 80%%. Dark Matter Armor has no durability thus cannot be damage while being worn. The Dark Matter Leggings are also used in the crafting of the Red Matter Leggings.
ntc2.projecte.dmboots.desc1: In addition to providing physical protection similar to the Diamond Boots, they reduce damage taken by 80%%. Dark Matter Armor has no durability thus cannot be damage while being worn. The Dark Matter Boots are also used in the crafting of the Red Matter Boots.
ntc2.projecte.gemhelm.desc1: Inheriting the protection and damage reduction of the Red Matter Helmet, the Gem Helmet also protects the wearer from drowning, provides night vision and allows the wearer to shoot lightning bolts.
ntc2.projecte.gemchest.desc1: Inheriting the protection and damage reduction of the Red Matter Chestplate, the Gem Chestplate also protects the wearer completely from fire and lava, and enables the wearer to create and fire explosions.
ntc2.projecte.gemlegs.desc1: Inheriting the protection and damage reduction of the Red Matter Leggings, the Gem Leggings enable rapid descent while flying. On landing, they will repel nearby mobs in a manner similar to the Interdiction Torch
ntc2.projecte.gemboots.desc1: Inheriting the protection and damage reduction of the Red Matter Boots, the Gem Boots also protects the wearer from fall damage (when not sprinting), provide a jump boost and slow the rate of any fall.
ntc2.projecte.emclink.subtitle: This lets you directly import items in your personal EMC storage, which you can access from Transmutation Table.
ntc2.cobaltingot.title: Coocoo for &9Cocobalt&r
ntc2.cobaltingot.subtitle: Find &9Cobalt&r in &6The Nether&r.
ntc2.cobaltingot.desc1: &9Cobalt&r is a special metal used for specific machines in this pack. It is required to progress into higher tiers of automation.
ntc2.osmiumingot.title: Ozzy &9Osmium&r
ntc2.osmiumingot.subtitle: Find &9Osmium&r in &6The End&r.
ntc2.osmiumingot.desc1: &9Osmium&r is a special metal used for specific machines in this pack. It is required to progress into higher tiers of automation.
ntc2.agricraft.welcome.title: Welcome to Agricraft
ntc2.agricraft.welcome.subtitle: The difficult part is getting 10,10,10
ntc2.grass.title: &dMowing the Lawn&r
ntc2.grass.subtitle: Take a look at some grass. Now break it. Get some seeds.
ntc2.grass.desc1: Agricraft seeds override most crop mechanics.
ntc2.info1.title: &2Don't harvest Mature plants.&r
ntc2.info1.desc1: It should be a general rule to make a separate wheat farm to provide food until you are well into Agricraft super crops. Mature plants cross-breed faster than seedlings, they create upgraded seeds faster. If you want food, make a farm. If you want to Upgrade or Cross-Breed plants, don't harvest them.
ntc2.info2.title: &2Upgrading Plants.&r
ntc2.info2.desc1: Near water, use a hoe to till five blocks of soil in a plus (+) pattern. Place 1 Agricraft Crop on the 4 OUTSIDE BLOCKS, and then a seed of your choice
ntc2.info3.title: &2Cross-Breeding Plants.&r
ntc2.info3.desc1: To Cross-Breed plants use the same layout as &n&aUpgrading Plants&r, but place two DIFFERENT plants, instead of four of the SAME plants, with tilled soil in the middle.
ntc2.info3.desc2: Place Crops TWICE to create a 'Crosscrop' on the open tilled location between the four Mature plants, as before
ntc2.info3.desc3: Then use the Watering Can, destroy Weeds or analyze new seedlings, just like when you're Upgrading plants.
ntc2.infosub.subtitle: Readme!
ntc2.mushrooms.subtitle: These will randomly spawn when crossbreeding potatoes and carrots
ntc2.metalseeds.subtitle: These type of plants require a kind of 'crux' under the plant to grow. Like an Ore.
ntc2.wheatseeds.title: Wheat Seeds
ntc2.potatoseeds.title: Potato Seeds
ntc2.carrotseeds.title: Carrot Seeds
ntc2.pumpkinseeds.title: Pumpkin Seeds
ntc2.pumpkinseeds.subtitle: Arguably the easiest way to Farm a ton of &eEMC&r early game
ntc2.melonseeds.title: Melon Seeds
ntc2.beetseeds.title: Beet Root Seeds
ntc2.brownmushseeds.title: Brown Mushroom Seeds
ntc2.redmushseeds.title: Red Mushroom Seeds
ntc2.harvestcraft.welcome.title: Welcome to Harvestcraft
ntc2.harvestcraft.readme.title: Eating a Variety
ntc2.harvestcraft.readme.subtitle: Readme!
ntc2.harvestcraft.readme.desc1: Eat as much variety as possible because you gain extra hearts from eatting new foods. Check out Spice of Life Guide Book.
ntc2.certus.title: Quartzy
ntc2.certus.subtitle: Get some Certus Quartz
ntc2.certus.desc1: &bCertus Quartz&r is one of the most-used materials in Applied Energistics 2.
ntc2.certus.desc2: It comes in two types, normal and charged. &bCharged Certus Quartz&r drops from its ore, but can also be made in the &6Fluid Encapsulator&r.
ntc2.certus.desc3: Mekanism also adds a way to craft it, but that's on Mekanism's side, not AE2's.
ntc2.skystone.subtitle: Requires pouring molten Blitz over Basalt
ntc2.skystone.desc1: Can be made with Tinkers Casting Basin and can also be made in the &6Fluid Encapsulator&r.
ntc2.fluix.title: Fluix Buddies
ntc2.fluix.subtitle: Get some Fluix Crystals
ntc2.fluix.desc1: &bFluix Crystals&r are another resource, but they don't generate naturally.
ntc2.fluix.desc2: Instead, &6insert Charged Certus Quartz, Nether Quartz, and Redstone dust into a Thermal Induction Smelter&r or the later game option is the Fluix Aggregator.
ntc2.ae2charger.title: Proprietary Hardware
ntc2.ae2charger.subtitle: Make a Charger
ntc2.ae2charger.desc1: The &bCharger&r accepts either FE/AE through its top/bottom sides, and uses it to &6charge a very small number of items&r.
ntc2.ae2charger.desc2: You can only charge certain items (the second task being a list of those); &cit does not charge every item that holds FE&r.
ntc2.ae2charger.desc3: Right-click the Charger while holding the item to insert it, and then right-click again to remove it.
ntc2.ae2charger.desc4: Fun fact: you can charge the Charger with a Crank!
ntc2.ae2charger.desc5: &cIt does not charge Certus Quartz into Charged Certus Quartz though.&r.
ntc2.purecrystals.title: Purity
ntc2.purecrystals.subtitle: Get some Pure Crystals
ntc2.purecrystals.desc1: The final new material is &bPure Crystals&r.
ntc2.purecrystals.desc2: To make Pure Crystals, throw a &bSeed&r of that type in some Water and just let it grow. It takes a &n&cvery long time&r, but eventually it will turn into a Pure Crystal.
ntc2.purecrystals.desc3: It is &6highly recommended to use Crystal Growth Accelerators&r, as they drastically reduce the time required.
ntc2.purecrystals.desc4: There are Pure variations of Nether Quartz, Certus Quartz, and Fluix Crystals.
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.title: Proprietary Energy
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.subtitle: Make an Energy Acceptor
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.desc1: Applied Energistics 2 does not use FE. Rather, it has &6its own energy system&r called "AE".
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.desc2: The &bEnergy Acceptor&r can convert FE to AE, at a rate of 2FE=1AE.
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.desc3: AE power can be &6transferred via any Cable&r from AE2.
ntc2.ae2energyacceptor.desc4: However, the &6ME Controller can also convert&r FE to AE, and at a much faster rate. You have to make that eventually anyway, so &6this quest is optional&r.
ntc2.ae2energycell.subtitle: Make an Energy Cell
ntc2.ae2energycell.desc1: &bEnergy Cells&r store AE power, acting as a backup in case the network stops receiving it externally.
ntc2.ae2energycell.desc2: The lower tier stores &6200,000 AE&r, and the higher stores &61,600,000 AE&r.
ntc2.vibrationchamber.title: What's that noise?
ntc2.vibrationchamber.subtitle: (Don't) Make a Vibration Chamber
ntc2.vibrationchamber.desc1: The &bVibration Chamber&r burns furnace fuels to generate AE.
ntc2.vibrationchamber.desc2: This is the only in-house way of generating power for AE2, but like... &6there's so many better ways&r to generate FE and then convert to AE that this doesn't really have any reason to exist.
ntc2.vibrationchamber.desc3: As such, &6this quest is entirely optional&r.
ntc2.growthaccelerator.title: Basically Impossible Without This
ntc2.growthaccelerator.subtitle: Make a Crystal Growth Accelerator
ntc2.growthaccelerator.desc1: &bCrystal Growth Accelerators&r use AE power to &6speed up the growth of adjacent crystal Seeds&r.
ntc2.growthaccelerator.desc2: It is powered from the top or bottom, and it speeds up Seeds that are &6touching its sides&r.
ntc2.growthaccelerator.desc3: You can have &6up to 5&r surrounding one Water block while still leaving room for you to throw Seeds in.
ntc2.inscriber.subtitle: Make an Inscriber
ntc2.inscriber.desc1: The &bInscriber&r is required to craft &6Processors&r, which are used very often in crafting recipes.
ntc2.inscriber.desc2: In the top slot, insert an &6Inscriber Press&r (more on that in the quest above), then insert the appropriate item in the center. Give it FE (&c&nnot AE&r) and it will slowly start working.
ntc2.inscriber.desc3: Inscribers are &6fairly hard to automate&r, as they can only have one item in each slot at a time. Placed upright, the top face is the &6top input&r, the bottom is the &6bottom input&r, and sides are both the &6middle input and the output&r.
ntc2.ae2compass.subtitle: Press and the Rest
ntc2.ae2compass.desc1: Normally, you have to use the &bMeteorite Compass&r to find meteorites, at the center of which will have a chest with a &6random Inscriber Press&r.
ntc2.ae2compass.desc2: This is fun the first couple times, but can get annoying when you have 6 Logic Presses and nothing else. It can also cause lag, due to world generation.
ntc2.ae2compass.desc3: So, &6we've added recipes for Presses and Sky Stone&r, to hopefully mitigate some of those issues. Meteorites won't spawn.
ntc2.ae2compass.desc4: &6Sky Stone&r requires pouring molten blitz over basalt
ntc2.ae2acceleration.subtitle: Make an Acceleration Card
ntc2.ae2acceleration.desc1: &bAcceleration Cards&r can be inserted into certain AE2 machines to &6make them work faster&r.
ntc2.ae2acceleration.desc2: You can install multiple to increase their work speed even more.
ntc2.mecontroller.title: ME!ME!ME!
ntc2.mecontroller.subtitle: Make an ME Controller
ntc2.mecontroller.desc1: The &bME Controller&r is the brain of every ME (matter-energy) network. &6You can only have one Controller multiblock per network.&r
ntc2.mecontroller.desc2: This quest will go over its &6construction&r, the quest above will explain how it works.
ntc2.mecontroller.desc3: When making the multiblock, &6prioritize how many faces are available&r; meaning, how many Cables can be attached directly.
ntc2.mecontroller.desc4: The multiblock must be a &67x7x7 or smaller&r.
ntc2.mecontroller.desc5: Controllers can only have a single axis with 2 connections; that is, it can be &6shaped like ⊥&r but &cnot +&r.
ntc2.mecontroller.desc6: The Controller can convert FE to AE, at a rate of 2FE=1AE.
ntc2.ae2channels.title: Change the Channel
ntc2.ae2channels.subtitle: Learn about Channels
ntc2.ae2channels.desc1: &bChannels&r are a system unique to AE2. Cables can only support so many channels, with &6each device taking up one&r.
ntc2.ae2channels.desc2: You can theoretically have an ME network &6without a Controller&r, but it would &6only be able to support 8 channels&r.
ntc2.ae2channels.desc3: Normal &6Cables can carry 8 channels&r, while &6Dense Cables can carry 32&r, though they cannot connect to devices directly.
ntc2.ae2channels.desc4: A Dense Cable can support 4 fully maxed normal Cables.
ntc2.ae2channels.desc5: Each face of an ME Controller &6provides up to 32 channels&r, limited by the Cable connecting to it.
ntc2.ae2channels.desc6: Channels will take the &6shortest path&r from the Controller to the device.
ntc2.ae2channellink.title: They're Very Complex, Sorry
ntc2.ae2channellink.subtitle: If that didn't explain it well enough, click this to go to the mod's wiki page on channels.
ntc2.networktool.subtitle: Make a Network Tool
ntc2.networktool.desc1: The &bNetwork Tool&r is used to see certain statistics about the ME network.
ntc2.networktool.desc2: Clicking the ME Controller with a Network Tool will show all machines in the ME network, along with &6how much power it is using per tick&r.
ntc2.networktool.desc3: Sneak right-clicking the Network Tool will open its GUI, allowing you to &6insert 9 stacks of upgrade Cards&r. When in a device GUI, the Tool's Cards will be available.
ntc2.ae2wrench.title: Wrenches
ntc2.ae2wrench.subtitle: Make a Wrench
ntc2.ae2wrench.desc: &bWrenches&r can be used to rotate blocks, and can be used on a part to &6instantly disassemble it&r.
ntc2.ae2glasscable.title: Basic Cables
ntc2.ae2glasscable.subtitle: Make ME Glass Cables
ntc2.ae2glasscable.desc1: &bME Glass Cables&r are the most basic form of ME Cable.
ntc2.ae2glasscable.desc2: They can &6carry 8 channels&r, and can &6support devices&r attached to them.
ntc2.ae2glasscable.desc3: &bME Covered Cables&r are &6functionally identical&r to Glass Cables.
ntc2.ae2colorcables.title: &4&l█&c&l█&6&l█&e&l█&2&l█&a&l█&b&l█&3&l█&1&l█&9&l█&d&l█
ntc2.ae2colorcables.subtitle: Make any colored Cable
ntc2.ae2colorcables.desc1: Cables of all kinds can be color-coded to prevent unwanted connections.
ntc2.ae2colorcables.desc2: &bColored Cables&r &6only connect to Cables of the same color&r, though all colors connect to normal Fluix Cables.
ntc2.ae2colorcables.desc3: This is especially useful for when you have several paths within a small area that you don't want interacting, to make sure channels only go along certain paths.
ntc2.ae2colorcables.desc4: Also, certain devices will match the color of the Cable they are on!
ntc2.quartzfiber.title: Technically You Already Had to Make These, But...
ntc2.quartzfiber.subtitle: Make Quartz Fiber
ntc2.quartzfiber.desc: &bQuartz Fiber&r can be placed between two Cables to &6allow energy, but &onot&r &6channels, to pass through&r.
ntc2.mesmartcable.title: Smart Cables
ntc2.mesmartcable.subtitle: Make ME Smart Cables
ntc2.mesmartcable.desc1: &bME Smart Cables&r have all the same functionality as normal ME Cables, but will &6display how many channels are passing through them&r.
ntc2.mesmartcable.desc2: In addition to being convenient, it also just looks super cool.
ntc2.medense.title: Dense Covered Cables
ntc2.medense.subtitle: Make ME Dense Covered Cables
ntc2.medense.desc1: &bME Dense Covered Cables&r can carry up to &632 channels&r, but cannot directly support devices.
ntc2.medense.desc2: Pre-P2P (we'll come back to &othat&r later), it would be smart to directly connect these to the Controller, and then from there branch off into normal Cables.
ntc2.smartdense.title: Dense Smart Cables
ntc2.smartdense.subtitle: Make ME Dense Smart Cables
ntc2.smartdense.desc: &bME Dense Smart Cables&r work exactly like Dense Covered Cables, but they &6show how many channels are passing through them&r.
ntc2.ae2facade.title: The C is Silent, and the S is Invisible
ntc2.ae2facade.subtitle: Make any Cable Facade
ntc2.ae2facade.desc1: &bCable Facades&r can be attached to any ME Cable, &6making that side look like the block it's made out of&r.
ntc2.ae2facade.desc2: Additionally, Torches, Levers, and the like can be placed on Facades, as if they were a solid block.
ntc2.ae2facade.desc3: Facades can be placed on the same face as a device, so you can make your Terminals etc flush with the wall.
ntc2.mechest.subtitle: Make an ME Chest
ntc2.mechest.desc1: The &bME Chest&r is the most simple way to use AE2 to store items.
ntc2.mechest.desc2: Click any side other than the top to insert a &bStorage Cell&r, and click the top to access items inside it.
ntc2.mechest.desc3: The ME Chest is capable of &6working independently&r of an ME Controller, as it can accept FE directly. However, if connected to a network, the network will also be able to access its contents.
ntc2.portablecell.title: Digital Backpack!
ntc2.portablecell.subtitle: Make a Portable Cell
ntc2.portablecell.desc1: &bPortable Cells&r works like a backpack, but using AE2 logic. It requires energy to work.
ntc2.portablecell.desc2: It also stores about half as much as the equivalent Storage Cell.
ntc2.meterminal.title: Storage Access
ntc2.meterminal.subtitle: Make an ME Terminal
ntc2.meterminal.desc1: The &bME Terminal&r is the first of many devices, and allows you to &6access all items in the ME network&r (we'll get to storing items in a bit).
ntc2.meterminal.desc2: On the left, you have several &6buttons&r. Their &6tooltips&r should be fairly self-explanatory.
ntc2.meterminal.desc3: The top right has a button to show what the system is &6auto-crafting&r, as well as 5 slots for &6View Cells&r. We'll cover both of those later.
ntc2.craftingterminal.subtitle: Make an ME Crafting Terminal
ntc2.craftingterminal.desc: The &bME Crafting Terminal&r works exactly like an ME Terminal, but &6has a 3x3 crafting grid&r.
ntc2.cellworkbench.title: Cells at Work
ntc2.cellworkbench.subtitle: Make a Cell Workbench
ntc2.cellworkbench.desc1: The &bCell Workbench&r allows you to &6configure Cells&r.
ntc2.cellworkbench.desc2: You can insert a &6Storage Cell&r into the top right slot, and then in the slots below set an &6item whitelist&r of what is allowed to enter that Cell. This is called &6partitioning&r.
ntc2.cellworkbench.desc3: An example use of this would be to put all ores into one cell, all ingots into another, etc. That way, the cell won't get full of any random junk you put into the system.
ntc2.cellworkbench.desc4: You can also click the Wrench button to automatically partition the Cell to what it's currently holding.
ntc2.cellworkbench.desc5: You can insert a &6Fuzzy Card&r to make that Cell ignore damage and nbt, and you can insert an &6Invert Card&r to make it a blacklist instead of a whitelist.
ntc2.viewcell.title: Filter
ntc2.viewcell.subtitle: Make a View Cell
ntc2.viewcell.desc: Partition a &bView Cell&r, and then insert it into the top right slots of Terminals to &6filter what's visible&r to match the View Cell's whitelist/blacklist.
ntc2.medrive.title: Storing Items
ntc2.medrive.subtitle: Make an ME Drive and Storage Cell
ntc2.medrive.desc1: The &bME Drive&r can store up to 10 &bStorage Cells&r, allowing their contents to be visible to the network.
ntc2.medrive.desc2: Storage Cells can store items, with higher tiers storing more.
ntc2.medrive.desc3: &oTechnically&r, Storage Cells store &6bytes&r, not items. A certain amount of bytes is required for unique items; &62 of the same item uses less bytes than 2 different items&r.
ntc2.medrive.desc4: &6Higher tier Cells have more bytes&r, but also require &6more bytes per unique item&r. That makes them more useful for storing a large amount of a small variety of items.
ntc2.medrive.desc5: Additionally, every cell is &6limited to 63 unique items&r.
ntc2.meimport.title: Insert inside ME
ntc2.meimport.subtitle: Make an ME Import Bus
ntc2.meimport.desc1: The &bME Import Bus&r will pull items from the inventory it is facing, inserting them into its ME network.
ntc2.meimport.desc2: In its GUI, you can set a &6whitelist&r. Defaulting to 1 item, up to 2 &6Capacity Cards&r can be installed to increase the amount to 9.
ntc2.meimport.desc3: You can also install a &6Fuzzy Card&r to make it ignore NBT, as well as &6Acceleration Cards&r to make it work faster.
ntc2.meexport.title: Output out of ME
ntc2.meexport.subtitle: Make an ME Export Bus
ntc2.meexport.desc1: The &bME Export Bus&r will push items (set by a whitelist in its GUI) from its ME network into the inventory it is facing.
ntc2.meexport.desc2: Its whitelist by default only has 1 slot, but can be upgraded to 9 with &6Capacity Cards&r.
ntc2.meexport.desc3: You can also install a &6Fuzzy Card&r to make it ignore NBT/Damage, as well as &6Acceleration Cards&r to make it work faster.
ntc2.meexport.desc4: Additionally, you can insert a &6Crafting Card&r to allow it to craft items to export if they run out. Naturally, this only works if the items can be auto-crafted by the network.
ntc2.metoggle.title: Disconnect
ntc2.metoggle.subtitle: Make an ME Toggle Bus
ntc2.metoggle.desc1: The &bME Toggle Bus&r, when given a redstone signal, will not allow channels or energy to pass through it. This effectively &6disconnects everything past it&r.
ntc2.metoggle.desc2: The &bInverted ME Toggle Bus&r does the opposite, disabling when not given a signal.
ntc2.levelemitter.subtitle: Make an ME Level Emitter
ntc2.levelemitter.desc1: The &bME Level Emitter&r will output a redstone signal &6when a specified item is above/below a specified amount&r.
ntc2.levelemitter.desc2: You can also set it to emit the signal when the ME network's &6energy is below a specified amount&r, so you can automatically start an emergency generator to power it back up.
ntc2.storagebus.title: External Storage
ntc2.storagebus.subtitle: Make an ME Storage Bus
ntc2.storagebus.desc1: The &bME Storage Bus&r, when placed on an inventory, will connect that inventory to the ME system.
ntc2.storagebus.desc2: In &6Bi-Directional&r mode, items can be pulled from it, as well as being pushed into it. When items are inserted into the ME system, they will try to go to Storage Buses that already have that item before Storage Cells.
ntc2.storagebus.desc3: In &6Extract Only&r, you can only pull from it.
ntc2.storagebus.desc4: In &6Insert Only&r and with &6no whitelist&r, items in it will not be available, and it will act as a lowest-possible priority destination for items.
ntc2.storagebus.desc5: In &6Insert Only&r and &6with a whitelist&r, items in the whitelist will enter that inventory, seemingly disappearing from the network.
ntc2.storagemonitor.subtitle: Make an ME Storage Monitor
ntc2.storagemonitor.desc1: The &bME Storage Monitor&r will display the amount of the set item in its storage.
ntc2.storagemonitor.desc2: To set the item, simply right-click the Monitor with it.
ntc2.storagemonitor.desc3: Right-click with an empty hand to unset items, and use a Wrench on it to lock it to an item.
ntc2.storagemonitor.desc4: The Storage Monitor is &6not a Drawer&r; you cannot punch it to remove items.
ntc2.capacitycard.subtitle: Make a Capacity Card
ntc2.capacitycard.desc1: &bCapacity Cards&r can be installed to certain devices to &6increase their max whitelist size&r.
ntc2.capacitycard.desc2: Generally, devices only have 1 slot available. Up to 2 Capacity Cards can be installed to bring it up to 9.
ntc2.fuzzycard.subtitle: Make a Fuzzy Card
ntc2.fuzzycard.desc1: The &bFuzzy Card&r can be installed to certain devices to allow them to match a specific range of damage, rather than specifically what is given to it.
ntc2.fuzzycard.desc2: There are 6 modes: &6Match Any&r, then &6Split Damage at 99%%&r, &675%%&r, &650%%&r, and &625%%&r.
ntc2.fuzzycard.desc3: Match Any makes it ignore damage entirely, and the Split Damages match when the damage is within that percentage of the full durability.
ntc2.redstonecard.subtitle: Make a Redstone Card
ntc2.redstonecard.desc1: The &bRedstone Card&r can be installed to certain devices to allow them to be controlled by a redstone signal.
ntc2.redstonecard.desc2: There are &6Always active&r, &6Active without signal&r, &6Active with signal&r, and &6Activate once per pulse&r.
ntc2.mesecurity.title: That Thing That Wireless Terminals Need
ntc2.mesecurity.subtitle: Make an ME Security Terminal
ntc2.mesecurity.desc1: The &bME Security Terminal&r allows you to configure what people are allowed to do with your ME network. Ownership of the network is decided by who places the Security Terminal.
ntc2.mesecurity.desc2: A &6Biometric Card&r can be inserted into the bottom left slot, then permissions can be toggled with the buttons on the right. Put the Biometric Card into one of the top slots to apply it.
ntc2.mesecurity.desc3: &6The owner always has all permissions, so they cannot have a Biometric Card.&r
ntc2.mesecurity.desc4: A blank Biometric Card means "anyone but the owner." A player can sneak right-click the Biometric Card to set it to themselves.
ntc2.mesecurity.desc5: And now, the only reason anyone ever actually makes a Security Terminal: you can &6insert a Wireless Terminal&r into the top right slot to &6bind it to that ME network&r.
ntc2.meaccesspoint.subtitle: Make an ME Wireless Access Point
ntc2.meaccesspoint.desc1: An &bME Wireless Access Point&r allows players &6within 16 blocks&r of itself to access the ME system using Wireless Terminals.
ntc2.meaccesspoint.desc2: You can add &6Wireless Boosters&r to the Access Point to &6increase the range&r, also increasing the cost. Having an entire stack installed increases the range to &6528 blocks&r, at the total cost of 4,100 AE/t.
ntc2.wirelessterminal.subtitle: Make a Wireless Terminal
ntc2.wirelessterminal.desc1: The &bWireless Terminal&r uses AE power to &6access its bound ME network wirelessly&r. It works exactly like an ME Terminal.
ntc2.wirelessterminal.desc2: You have to bind it to the network in a &6Security Terminal&r, and you must be within range of a &6Wireless Access Point&r.
ntc2.wirelessterminal.desc3: It uses &61 AE/t for every block&r between you and the Access Point while being used.
ntc2.wct.subtitle: Make a Wireless Crafting Terminal
ntc2.wct.desc1: The &bWireless Crafting Terminal&r (which comes from an addon, &eAE2 Wireless Terminals&r, not AE2) is an upgraded Wireless Terminal that has a 3x3 crafting grid.
ntc2.wct.desc2: Additionally, it can store 4 View Cells, has slots for your armor and curios, has a trash can slot, and has slots for an &6Infinity Booster Card&r and &6Magnet Card&r, each of which are explained in their own quests.
ntc2.wct.desc3: Additionally additionally, you can access it using a keybind. The control name is "Open Wireless Crafting Terminal."
ntc2.magnetcard.subtitle: Make a Magnet Card
ntc2.magnetcard.desc1: A &bMagnet Card&r can be installed to the WCT to allow it to &6automatically insert picked up items into the ME network&r, instead of your inventory.
ntc2.magnetcard.desc2: When installed, the WCT gets two new buttons: on the right, you can &6toggle&r the Magnet Card; directly above the Card slot, you can edit the Card's &6filter&r.
ntc2.magnetcard.desc3: In the Magnet Filter GUI, you can add up to 27 items to be in either a whitelist of items to insert or a blacklist of items to not insert. You can also set it to ignore damage/nbt and use the ore dictionary.
ntc2.infinitybooster.subtitle: Get an Infinity Booster Card
ntc2.infinitybooster.desc: The &bInfinity Booster Card&r can be installed onto the WCT to give it an &6infinite range&r that also works &6across dimensions&r.
ntc2.meioport.title: MEIOP
ntc2.meioport.subtitle: Make an ME IO Port
ntc2.meioport.desc1: The &bME IO Port&r lets you &6empty or fill a Storage Cell&r using the network.
ntc2.meioport.desc2: This is particularly useful if, for instance, you are upgrading a Cell and need to empty it first. In that case, use &6Transfer data to Network&r.
ntc2.meioport.desc3: Another use would be if you partition a Cell, and then want to make sure only that Cell has those items. In this case, use &6Transfer Data to Storage Cell&r.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.title: Spatial Storage is Complex, So This Quest is &lLong&r
ntc2.spatialcontainment.subtitle: Make a Spatial Containment Structure
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc1: The &bSpatial Containment Structure&r is a multiblock that allows you to take an area in the world and store it digitally.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc2: Each &bSpatial Storage Cell&r can only hold a specific volume. A 2³ Cell can hold, at most, a 2x2x2 volume. A 16³ Cell holds up to 16x16x16, and so on.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc3: To set the volume to be moved, place 3 &bSpatial Pylons&r strips along the X, Y, and Z directions, branching off from a corner.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc4: To better visualize, &6imagine a cube&r. &6Three edges&r of the cube should be Spatial Pylons, and in &6the corner where they meet&r should be either a Cable or the Spatial IO Port.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc5: The volume to be stored in the Cell is a smaller cube, &6one layer deeper&r than the full cube.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc6: If using a 2³ cube, the outer cube would be 4x4x4, with 9 Spatial Pylons (3 on each side). If they are placed correctly, they will glow purple. If not, they will glow red.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc7: Spatial Pylons are &6extremely power-hungry&r, so you may need to provide the system some &6Dense Energy Cells&r.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc8: You can make them more efficient by adding more rows of Spatial Pylons. Break any second Pylon in an existing corner, replace it with a Cable, and then from there place a line of Pylons according to how large the volume is.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc9: All Spatial Pylons in the network are assumed to be in the same SCS, so you should probably &6isolate each to their own subnetwork&r.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc10: Once the Spatial Pylons are set up, connect a &bSpatial IO Port&r. Insert a Spatial Storage Cell in the left slot, give it a redstone pulse, and it will store the blocks in the SCS, removing them from the world. The Cell is moved to the output slot after.
ntc2.spatialcontainment.desc11: The Cell technically doesn't just store the blocks; instead, it &6swaps what it currently has&r with what's in the SCS.
ntc2.ae2breakplace.title: Breaking and Placing
ntc2.ae2breakplace.subtitle: Make ME Annihilation/Formation Planes
ntc2.ae2breakplace.desc1: The &bME Annihilation Plane&r &6destroys the block it is facing&r, placing the drops into the ME network.
ntc2.ae2breakplace.desc2: It &6cannot be filtered&r, but will only break blocks if it has &6somewhere to put them&r. That means, if Cells are partitioned to not accept it, it will not be broken.
ntc2.ae2breakplace.desc3: The &bME Formation Plane&r will &6instantly place any block that is added to the network&r. As such, it pretty much &6has to be in its own subnetwork&r.
ntc2.ae2breakplace.desc4: You can set a &6whitelist&r of what it can place (which can be increased with &6Capacity Cards&r), as well as toggle if blocks are placed or &6dropped as items&r.
ntc2.ae2silk.title: &bME Identity Annihilation Plane&r
ntc2.ae2silk.subtitle: Make an ME Identity Annihilation Plane&r
ntc2.ae2silk.desc: The &bME Identity Annihilation Plane&r works just like a regular Annihilation Plane, but applies &6Silk Touch&r.
ntc2.mattercompressor.title: &bMatter Condenser&r
ntc2.mattercompressor.subtitle: Make a Matter Condenser
ntc2.mattercompressor.desc1: The &bMatter Condenser&r &6destroys items/fluids&r, condensing them into either &6Matter Balls&r or &6Singularities&r. Or, ya know, just deleting them.
ntc2.mattercompressor.desc2: Insert a Storage Component into the top slot, click the button on the right to choose what you're making, and then just pump it full of trash.
ntc2.mattercannon.subtitle: Make a Matter Cannon
ntc2.mattercannon.desc1: The &bMatter Cannon&r shoots certain items as projectiles, dealing damage.
ntc2.mattercannon.desc2: In order of damage, these items are &6Matter Balls&r, &6Iron Nuggets&r, &6Tin Nuggets&r and &6Lead Nuggets&r. The damage ranges from 1 to 11 hearts.
ntc2.mattercannon.desc3: To load the Matter Cannon, &6treat it like a Storage Cell&r and insert the specific item into it. The most convenient way for this would be an ME Chest.
ntc2.mattercannon.desc4: Additionally, projectiles will break blocks. More powerful ammo will break more.
ntc2.colorapplicator.subtitle: Make a Color Applicator
ntc2.colorapplicator.desc1: The &bColor Applicator&r uses &bPaint Balls&r to paint blocks. In particular, it can &6paint ME Cables&r.
ntc2.colorapplicator.desc2: To &6load Paint Balls&r in, &6treat the Color Applicator like a Storage Cell&r and insert the Paint Balls in there. The most convenient way to do this would be an ME Chest.
ntc2.colorapplicator.desc3: You can swap between different color Paint Balls inside by scrolling while sneaking.
ntc2.quantumring.title: Quantum Network Bridge
ntc2.quantumring.subtitle: Make a Quantum Network Bridge
ntc2.quantumring.desc1: The &bNetwork Bridge&r is a multiblock that works in pairs to allow you to wirelessly connect to ME networks at a distance.
ntc2.quantumring.desc2: Make a ring of 8 &bME Quantum Rings&r around an &bME Quantum Link Chamber&r to form the multiblock.
ntc2.quantumring.desc3: To link two Quantum Network Bridges, &bthrow down a Singularity and Ender Dust&r, and cause an &6explosion nearby&r. This will create a pair of linked &bQuantum Entangled Singularities&r.
ntc2.quantumring.desc4: It would be a good idea to rename these in an Anvil, so as not to confuse them with other pairs.
ntc2.quantumring.desc5: Insert one Quantum Entangled Singularity into each Quantum Link Chamber to connect them.
ntc2.quantumring.desc6: &6Jumpstart the distant Bridge&r with some power to turn it on, at which point it will start drawing power from the home Bridge.
ntc2.quantumring.desc7: At this point, connecting ME Cables to one of the 4 center Bridge blocks, and it will be on the same network as the other end.
ntc2.meinterface.subtitle: Make an ME Interface
ntc2.meinterface.desc1: The &bME Interface&r is probably the most powerful device in the mod.
ntc2.meinterface.desc2: Any item piped into it will instantly be sent to the ME network.
ntc2.meinterface.desc3: You can insert an item (including the amount) into one of the &6Config&r slots, and it will always try to keep that many available to be pulled out.
ntc2.meinterface.desc4: With the above two in mind, the Interface can &6function as both an Import &oand&r&6 Export Bus&r at the same time. You can set up to 9 items to store in the Interface and then pipe out, and then also pipe items into the Interface to enter the system!
ntc2.meinterface.desc5: Certain mods will treat the the ME Interface as a &6chest containing everything in the network&r. Most don't, however.
ntc2.meinterface.desc6: Notably, you can &6point a Storage Bus from another network at it&r, and the other network will be able to access everything in the Interface's network, but not vice versa. This smaller network (the one with the Interface) is called a &6subnetwork&r.
ntc2.meinterface.desc7: In the picture below, the blue subnetwork can access items from the red network, but not the other way around.
ntc2.meinterface.desc8: The main reason you would use ME Interfaces, however, is &6autocrafting&r. That is explained in the quests above.
ntc2.mepattern.subtitle: Make an ME Pattern Terminal
ntc2.mepattern.desc1: The &bME Pattern Terminal&r allows you to set a recipe in its crafting grid, then &6encode&r the pattern to a &bBlank Pattern&r.
ntc2.mepattern.desc2: You can also set if the recipe allows &6item substitutions&r; for instance, if a chest recipe will use any planks.
ntc2.mepattern.desc3: You can also toggle from &6Crafting Patterns&r, which just do normal crafting recipes, to &6Processing Patterns&r, which sends items out of the network to be processed externally.
ntc2.mepattern.desc4: With Processing Patterns, you can set up to &69 item inputs&r and &63 item outputs&r, as well as the amount of each.
ntc2.mepattern.desc5: Encoded Patterns are inserted into ME Interfaces. For Crafting Patterns, the Interface has to &6aim at a Molecular Assembler&r. For Processing Patterns, the Interface has to &6aim at any inventory&r, as long as the final result is inserted into the network from any source after.
ntc2.mepattern.desc6: You can aim the Interface using a &6Wrench&r, or by using the flat Interface instead.
ntc2.craftingcpu.title: Crafting CPU
ntc2.craftingcpu.subtitle: Make a Crafting CPU
ntc2.craftingcpu.desc1: The &bCrafting CPU&r is a multiblock machine that manages a single auto-craft task from start to finish.
ntc2.craftingcpu.desc2: The CPU must be a cuboid, with at least 1 &bCrafting Co-Processing Unit&r and some &bCrafting Storage&r. &bCrafting Units&r are simply a filler block.
ntc2.craftingcpu.desc3: The &6more Crafting Co-Processing Units&r, the &6more subtasks&r it can handle at once. For instance, if making a Bookcase, it can do Log→Planks at the same time as Paper+Leather→Books (assuming those recipes also exist in the network).
ntc2.craftingcpu.desc4: Complex recipes require more Crafting Storage.
ntc2.craftingmonitor.subtitle: Make a Crafting Monitor
ntc2.craftingmonitor.desc: The &bCrafting Monitor&r can be incorporated into a Crafting CPU and it will &6display the current crafting task&r.
ntc2.interfaceterminal.subtitle: Make an ME Interface Terminal
ntc2.interfaceterminal.desc1: The &bME Interface Terminal&r will show all ME Interfaces on the network, allowing you to add/remove recipes at a distance.
ntc2.interfaceterminal.desc2: Fun fact: you can &6rename Interfaces&r in an Anvil! That way, you could aim a renamed Interface at a Chest, then from there have pipes and stuff that automates the recipe externally, but the Interface Terminal would show its name instead of "Chest."
ntc2.molecularassemblar.subtitle: Make a Molecular Assembler
ntc2.molecularassemblar.desc1: The &bMolecular Assembler&r automatically crafts items using Encoded Patterns.
ntc2.molecularassemblar.desc2: When used with an ME Interface, it will use its Patterns.
ntc2.molecularassemblar.desc3: They can technically be used standalone, but then they can only have one Pattern.
ntc2.molecularassemblar.desc4: Either way, Molecular Assemblers &6do not take up Channels&r, though it can carry them.
ntc2.molecularassemblar.desc5: You can add &6Acceleration Cards&r to them, making them craft items faster.
ntc2.craftingcard.subtitle: Make a Crafting Card
ntc2.craftingcard.desc1: The &bCrafting Card&r can be placed in certain devices to &6allow it to make autocraft requests&r when needed.
ntc2.craftingcard.desc2: For instance, an Export Bus can have a Crafting Card, and it will try to craft the item it's exporting if none are in the network.
ntc2.p2p1.title: Point-to-Point
ntc2.p2p1.subtitle: Make a P2P Tunnel
ntc2.p2p1.desc1: &bP2P&r is one of the more complex (and definitely the most useful) concepts in AE2.
ntc2.p2p1.desc2: A pair of &bP2P Tunnels&r will essentially teleport certain things from one end to the other. You can only have one input tunnel, but several output tunnels.
ntc2.p2p1.desc3: The most common one is the &bP2P Tunnel - ME&r, which essentially &6teleports channels&r.
ntc2.p2p1.desc4: Being able to teleport connections is staggeringly powerful. A pair of P2P Tunnels only use 2 channels, but can transfer 32 channels through them.
ntc2.p2p1.desc5: That means a single Dense Cable carrying only P2P Tunnels, each carrying separate full Dense Cables, can carry 32*32 channels. That's &61024 channels &nthrough a single Cable&r!
ntc2.p2p1.desc6: The blue network connects all devices to a Controller, and the red network only serves to power the P2P Tunnels.
ntc2.p2p1.desc7: Sneak right-click on the P2P Tunnel you wish to be the input with a &bMemory Card&r, then right-click all the outputs with it to connect them.
ntc2.p2p2.title: Maximizing Your Network
ntc2.p2p2.subtitle: Learn what makes P2P &ocomplex&r
ntc2.p2p2.desc1: To make the &bmost out of P2P&r, you're going to need to make &6two different ME networks&r.
ntc2.p2p2.desc2: One Controller multiblock is the main one, with &6every visible face attached to an input P2P Tunnel - ME&r.
ntc2.p2p2.desc3: The second Controller Multiblock would support &6the ME Cables powering the P2P&r.
ntc2.p2p2.desc4: Use regular Cables to &6connect all the input P2Ps to a Dense Cable&r, then to the &6second Controller&r, and then just &6branch that to everywhere&r you want to use channels. Go down to a non-Dense Cable, &6smack an output P2P Tunnel on it, and then connect the Cables to that&r.
ntc2.p2pstyles.title: I Teleported Dihydrogen Monoxide
ntc2.p2pstyles.subtitle: Learn about other types of P2P
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc1: There are several other kinds of &bP2P Tunnel aside from ME&r. To get them, right-click certain items on an ME Tunnel. They stay that type when picked up with a Wrench.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc2: &bFE&r: Click with &6any FE cable&r. It teleports FE from the input and spreads it across all outputs.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc3: &bFluid&r: Click with a &6Bucket&r. It teleports fluids from the input and spreads it across all outputs.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc4: &bItem&r: Click with a &6Hopper, or anything that moves items&r. It teleports items from the input to outputs sequentially.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc5: &bRedstone&r: Click with &6anything Redstone&r. It teleports redstone signals from the input to all outputs equally.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc6: &bLight&r: Click with a &6Torch or Glowstone&r. It reads the light level of the input and then emits that light level out of all outputs. Kind of useful if you put the input outside facing the sun, so the outputs all show about what time of day it is.
ntc2.p2pstyles.desc7: To get back to &bME&r, click it with an ME Cable.
ntc2.mecircetch.title: &bME Circuit Etcher&r
ntc2.mecircetch.subtitle: Make an ME Circuit Etcher
ntc2.mecircetch.desc: The &bME Circuit Etcher&r can make Processors from their base ingredients, &6without making Printed Circuits&r. Additionally, each slot can have an entire stack rather than a single item.
ntc2.lazyae2gen.desc1: It can accept an &6Acceleration Card&r. At the top right of the GUI, you can choose the input/output of every face.
ntc2.lazyae2gen.desc2: This is from &eLazy AE2&r, an addon.
ntc2.pulsecent.subtitle: Make a Pulse Centrifuge
ntc2.pulsecent.desc: The &bPulse Centrifuge&r performs in-world crystal seed growing operations, &6purifying Crystals of all types&r.
ntc2.fluixagg.subtitle: Make a Fluix Aggregator
ntc2.fluixagg.desc: The &bFluix Aggregator&r performs in-world Fluix Crystal crafting operations, among certain other recipes.
ntc2.crystalenergizer.title: Basically a Certus Quartz charger
ntc2.crystalenergizer.subtitle: Make a Crystal Energizer
ntc2.crystalenergizer.desc1: &bCrystal Energizer&r use AE power to &6make regular Certus Quartz into the Charged variant&r.
ntc2.levmain.subtitle: Make an ME Level Maintainer
ntc2.levmain.desc1: The &bME Level Maintainer&r will &6automatically create crafting processes&r when specified items are &6below a specified threshold&r.
ntc2.levmain.desc2: Place up to 5 items in the left slots, set the minimum amount to maintain in the center, then how many it tries to craft on the right.
ntc2.pau.subtitle: Make a Preemptive Assembly Unit
ntc2.pau.desc1: The &bPreemptive Assembly Unit&r works like an ME Interface. It can be given 9 recipes, 9 items to keep supplied, and has 9 input slots.
ntc2.pau.desc2: However, the PAU &6tries to output the max amount of items it can&r, rather than waiting until a recipe is completed.
ntc2.massass.title: Mass Assembler
ntc2.massass.subtitle: Make a Mass Assembler
ntc2.massass.desc1: The &bMass Assembler&r is a multiblock machine that &6functions like a Molecular Assembler&r, but is &6faster&r and holds &6more recipes&r.
ntc2.massass.desc2: Every edge has to be made out of &bMass Assembler Frames&r, and the faces have to be made out of &bMass Assembler Vents&r.
ntc2.massass.desc3: Inside, every block must be either an &bMA Pattern Provider&r or an &bMA Crafting Coprocessor&r. Each Pattern Provider adds 36 slots for patterns, and each Crafting Coprocessor makes it faster.
ntc2.massass.desc4: One &bMass Assembler Controller&r must be placed on one of the walls, replacing a Vent. This is where Cables are connected. Right-click it to form the multiblock.
ntc2.packauto.title: PackagedAuto
ntc2.packauto.subtitle: Learn how to use PackagedAuto
ntc2.packauto.desc1: &ePackagedAuto&r is an AE2 addon that allows you to make &6autocraft recipes that use more than 9 items&r.
ntc2.packauto.desc2: To begin with, place down a &bPackage Recipe Encoder&r. Place 2 &bPackage Recipe Holders&r into the top left slot. Each can hold up to 20 recipes.
ntc2.packauto.desc3: On the right side of the GUI, you can cycle through all the different crafting recipe options. &6Processing&r will simply dump all ingredients at once, &6Ordered&r will send the items in the order you put them in, then the rest are for &ePackagedExCrafting&r (we'll come back to those later).
ntc2.packauto.desc4: In the bottom slots, set the recipe. Inputs on left, outputs on right. Once you are happy with your recipe, click &6Save&r at the top to save it to the Holder.
ntc2.packauto.desc5: Take these 2 Holders with their recipes. Insert one into a &bPackager&r and one into an &bUnpackager&r, both of which must be on the system.
ntc2.packauto.desc6: The recipe will now be available in Terminals etc. Items will enter the Packager, become Recipe Packages, then be sent to the Unpackager, which will unpack them, &6exporting them into an adjacent inventory&r.
ntc2.packauto.desc7: At this point, treat the Unpackager like you would an ME Interface. Place it next to an inventory, then use some other method of crafting items outside of the ME system, then pipe the finished item into the system to complete the crafting operation.
ntc2.packexc.title: PackagedExCrafting
ntc2.packexc.subtitle: Learn how to use PackagedExCrafting
ntc2.packexc.desc1: &ePackagedExCrafting&r is an addon for both &ePackagedAuto&r and &eExtended Crafting&r, designed to bridge the gap between them.
ntc2.packexc.desc2: Essentially, while in the Recipe Encoder, set the recipe type to the Extended Crafting block you want the recipe to use, then set the recipe.
ntc2.packexc.desc3: Place down the &bPackage Crafter&r of the type you want to use adjacent to the Unpackager with the Recipe Holder you just made, and it will use that to craft the item.
ntc2.packexc.desc4: If the Package Crafter is connected to the ME system, it will automatically send the craft result to storage, completing the crafting operation.
ntc2.wirelesspattern.title: Wireless Pattern-making Terminals
ntc2.wirelesspattern.subtitle: Make a Wireless Pattern/Interface Terminal
ntc2.wirelesspattern.desc: &eAE2 Wireless Terminals&r adds &bWireless Terminals&r for Pattern and Interface Terminals. They work exactly as you would expect.
ntc2.universalterm.title: All For One
ntc2.universalterm.subtitle: Make any Wireless Universal Terminal
ntc2.universalterm.desc1: The &bWireless Universal Terminal&r can work as any Wireless Terminal you add onto it.
ntc2.universalterm.desc2: It can be crafted by combining (almost) any Terminal with any other Wireless Terminal. You can also add more Terminals by crafting them with the Universal Terminal.
ntc2.universalterm.desc3: Sneak right-click the Universal Terminal to cycle through its types.
ntc2.rftbook.subtitle: Get the Technology Guide
ntc2.rftbook.desc1: The &bTechnology Guide&r has information on all of &9McJty&r's mods, like &eRFTools&r and its addons.
ntc2.rftbook.desc2: At this time, its documentation is not 100%% complete, so you will not be able to fully rely on the book to teach you everything.
ntc2.smartwrench.title: iWrench
ntc2.smartwrench.subtitle: Make a Smart Wrench
ntc2.smartwrench.desc1: The &bSmart Wrench&r comes in two modes. Right-click the air to swap between them.
ntc2.smartwrench.desc2: In normal mode, you can right-click blocks to turn them, and sneak right-click RFTools blocks to break them instantly.
ntc2.smartwrench.desc3: &6Select mode&r is used to &6bind blocks together&r. Sneak right-click the block you want to bind to, and then right-click all the blocks you want to bind to it.
ntc2.rftcoalgen.title: It Generates Energy &nUsing&r Coal, It Doesn't Make Coal
ntc2.rftcoalgen.subtitle: Make a Coal Generator
ntc2.rftcoalgen.desc1: The &bCoal Generator&r generates 36,000 FE at 60 FE/t per Coal.
ntc2.rftcoalgen.desc2: It can only burn Coal, Charcoal, and Coal Blocks, but it can charge items directly.
ntc2.blazagi.title: Rod Spinner
ntc2.blazagi.subtitle: Make a Blaze Agitator
ntc2.blazagi.desc1: The &bBlaze Agitator&r is used to make &6Blazing Rods&r, which are used in the &bBlazing Generator&r to make FE.
ntc2.blazagi.desc2: Using FE, it can charge up to 9 Blazing Rods at a time. &6Adjacent Rods make each other process faster.&r In the center, you can lock slots so they don't get sent to the output when done. It would be a good idea to &6lock the center slots on each side&r, so the other 5 slots are always boosted.
ntc2.blazinf.subtitle: Make a Blazing Infuser
ntc2.blazinf.desc1: The &bBlazing Infuser&r is used to &6make Blazing Rods even more powerful&r.
ntc2.blazinf.desc2: To do this, provide FE and give it &6a full stack of certain catalyst items&r. The Technology Guide (or the [?] button in the GUI) has a list of all catalysts and what they do.
ntc2.endergenic.subtitle: Make an Endergenic Generator setup
ntc2.endergenic.desc1: &bEndergenic Generators&r are extremely intricate machines that &6generate FE when firing and receiving Ender Pearls to each other&r.
ntc2.endergenic.desc2: An Endergenic Generator has 3 modes: &6idle&r, &6charging&r, and &6holding&r. The Generator cycles through these when given redstone pulses.
ntc2.endergenic.desc3: While in charging mode, there is a 15 tick window in which it can receive an Ender Pearl. The closer it is to the 10th tick, the more FE is produced.
ntc2.endergenic.desc4: If a Generator in charging mode receives a Pearl, it immediately goes into holding mode. Holding a Pearl drains FE.
ntc2.endergenic.desc5: Using a &6Smart Wrench&r (or any other compatible wrench), you can link Endergenic Generators in a cycle. When the first Generator gets a signal while in holding mode, it will throw the Pearl to the linked Generator.
ntc2.endergenic.desc6: Pearls are introduced into the cycle using the &bPearl Injector&r. Place the Injector adjacent (or directly above) to the first Endergenic Generator, and it will inject Ender Pearls it has stored when it gets a redstone pulse.
ntc2.endergenic.desc7: The &bEnder Monitor&r can output a signal when the Generator on its purple side shoots a Pearl, receives a Pearl, or loses a Pearl.
ntc2.endergeniclink.title: Click here for an image guide for an example setup
ntc2.endergeniclink.subtitle: &7A single Pearl with this setup generates about 1.74 million FE&r
ntc2.rftpowercell.title: Multiblock Power Tower
ntc2.rftpowercell.subtitle: Make a Powercell
ntc2.rftpowercell.desc1: &bPowercells&r come in three tiers, each storing more FE. If you place Powercells next to each other, they will connect and form a multiblock, &6combining their storage&r into one larger pool.
ntc2.rftpowercell.desc2: You have to use a &bSmart Wrench&r to allow it to input or output energy from that side. Blue is input, yellow is output.
ntc2.dimcells.title: Dimensional Cells
ntc2.dimcells.subtitle: Make a Dimensional Cell
ntc2.dimcells.desc1: &bDimensional Cells&r are store FE. You can right-click any face with a Smart Wrench to toggle between input (blue), output (orange), and neither.
ntc2.dimcells.desc2: Dimensional Cells come in three tiers: &bSimple&r, which store &6250,000FE&r; regular, which store &61,000,000FE&r; and &bAdvanced&r, which store &64,000,000FE&r. Higher tiers can also transfer more FE/t.
ntc2.dimcells.desc3: Dimensional Cells can wirelessly connect to each other to pool their storage using &bPowercell Cards&r.
ntc2.dimcells.desc4: Place a Powercell Card into the top left slot of the Dimensional Cell GUI, then place another in the slot that says &6Link&r. Place the newly linked Powercell Card into the top left of another Dimensional Cell to link them together.
ntc2.dimcells.desc5: &6Every linked Dimensional Cell will show as containing the sum of their combined storage.&r So, two linked Powercells would each say they have 2,000,000FE, but if you discharge one it also discharges the other. This is a great way to wirelessly transport power across large distances, though it loses efficiency the further away they are.
ntc2.rftteleporter.title: Beam Me Up
ntc2.rftteleporter.subtitle: Make a teleportation system
ntc2.rftteleporter.desc1: The &bMatter Receiver&r acts as a destination for teleporting. In its GUI you can give it a name and set if its private or not. You can also set a whitelist of players at the bottom, so they can use it even if it's set to private.
ntc2.rftteleporter.desc2: The &bMatter Transmitter&r will send the player standing on it to the desired location. Both the Receiver and Transmitter require FE to function, the amount of which increases based on distance.
ntc2.rftteleporter.desc3: The &bDialing Device&r will allow you to connect a nearby Matter Transmitter to any Matter Receiver you have access to. Click a Transmitter from the top and a Receiver from the bottom, then click either &6Dial&r to make a permanent connection, or &6Dial Once&r for a temporary one. Then, simply stand on the Transmitter and away you'll go!
ntc2.rftporter.title: Transportalponder
ntc2.rftporter.subtitle: Make a Charged Porter
ntc2.rftporter.desc1: The &bCharged Porter&r allows you to teleport to a bound Matter Receiver &6from anywhere in any dimension&r. Longer distances require more FE.
ntc2.rftporter.desc2: Sneak right-click the Porter on a Receiver to bind it.
ntc2.rftporter2.title: Transportalponderer
ntc2.rftporter2.subtitle: Make an Advanced Charged Porter
ntc2.rftporter2.desc: The &bAdvanced Charged Porter&r stores more FE and can have &6up to 8 bound Receivers&r. Sneak right-click on the air to choose which Receiver to teleport to.
ntc2.rftdestanal.title: Is It Safe?
ntc2.rftdestanal.subtitle: Make a Destination Analyzer
ntc2.rftdestanal.desc1: If the Matter Receiver does not have enough FE, teleporting to it will cause pretty much instant death. The &bDestination Analyzer&r lets you know if it's safe to use.
ntc2.rftdestanal.desc2: The Destination Analyzer is entirely passive and does not require FE. You can place it next to the Dialing Device to enable the &6Check&r button, which will say if it's safe.
ntc2.rftdestanal.desc3: &oOr&r, if you're cool, you could place it next to the Matter Transmitter, and if it's dangerous &cthe beam will glow &4&lred&r.
ntc2.rftmatboost.title: It's Safe.
ntc2.rftmatboost.subtitle: Make a Matter Booster
ntc2.rftmatboost.desc1: The &bMatter Booster&r can be placed next to a Matter Transmitter to allow it to &6safely teleport you to an unpowered Matter Receiver&r.
ntc2.rftmatboost.desc2: Well, "safely." &cIt will still damage you&r, but it won't outright kill you.
ntc2.rftcrafter1.subtitle: Make a Crafter Tier 1
ntc2.rftcrafter1.desc1: &bCrafters&r allow you to &6automatically craft items&r using their internal inventories. Higher tiers can store more recipes.
ntc2.rftcrafter1.desc2: At the top, click one of the recipe slots and then put in the recipe you want it to craft, then click &6Apply&r. You can also toggle whether that recipe will keep one of each ingredient in their slot, as well as if the results go into the output slots or back into the input slots.
ntc2.rftcrafter1.desc3: Click the &6R&r button (in the GUI, not your keyboard) to remember the current slot layout, only allowing those items into those slots. Click &6F&r to forget them.
ntc2.rftcrafter1.desc4: At the bottom right, you can change the redstone control mode and the speed that it crafts items at.
ntc2.rftcrafter2.subtitle: Make a Crafter Tier 2
ntc2.rftcrafter2.desc: The &bCrafter Tier 2&r has &64 crafting recipes&r instead of 2.
ntc2.rftcrafter3.subtitle: Make a Crafter Tier 3
ntc2.rftscreens.subtitle: Make a Screen setup
ntc2.rftscreens.desc1: &bScreens&r can display various things in your base in the world, such as the amount of energy in a machine, specific items in an inventory, if a certain wireless redstone signal is powered, and much much more.
ntc2.rftscreens.desc2: Screens require power, which is provided via a nearby &bScreen Controller&r. In its GUI, click &6Scan&r to connect to nearby Screens, and &6Detach&r to disconnect from them.
ntc2.rftscreens.desc3: Right-click a Screen with a Smart Wrench to change its &6display mode&r. The Screen can be 1x1, 2x2, or 3x3, and each size can be invisible.
ntc2.modularstorage.title: Digital Chest
ntc2.modularstorage.subtitle: Make a Modular Storage
ntc2.modularstorage.desc1: The &bModular Storage&r block is used to store items. Depending on the &bStorage Module&r installed, it can hold up to 300 stacks.
ntc2.modularstorage.desc2: Install a Storage Module by inserting it into the &6top left slot on the bottom left&r, then click the L button to lock it. If removed, &6the items will stay in the Storage Module&r item, not the block.
ntc2.modularstorage.desc3: At the bottom left, you can also insert a &6Filter Module&r. In its GUI (which you open by right-clicking in-hand), you can set a list of up to 30 items. You can set it to be a whitelist or a blacklist, whether to use oredic, the usual sorting stuff.
ntc2.modularstorage.desc4: On the left, you have a 3x3 crafting grid. It can craft using stored items. It also has buttons to decide how many it should craft.
ntc2.modularstorage.desc5: Above the crafting grid, you can &6store up to 6 recipes&r. Double-clicking a stored recipe will fill the grid instantly.
ntc2.remotestorage.subtitle: Make a Remote Storage
ntc2.remotestorage.desc1: The &bRemote Storage&r block can house up to 4 &6Storage Modules&r. To be accessed, you have to insert a &bRemote Storage Module&r to the right of any of them (which one specifically doesn't really matter). It also &6requires FE to run&r.
ntc2.remotestorage.desc2: Take the linked Remote Storage Module and treat it like a regular Storage Module, that is, &6insert it into a Modular Storage or Storage Tablet&r.
ntc2.remotestorage.desc3: In the Modular Storage or Storage Tablet, you can click the very bottom-left C button to &6cycle through all Storage Modules&r in the Remote Storage block. Other than that, it works exactly the same as regular.
ntc2.remotestorage.desc4: You can have multiple Modular Storages or Storage Tablets connected to the same Remote Storage.
ntc2.storagescanner.title: Central Storage
ntc2.storagescanner.subtitle: Make a Storage Scanner
ntc2.storagescanner.desc1: The &bStorage Scanner&r can &6remotely access inventories&r in an area around it. Set the radius in the bottom left corner then click &6Scan&r.
ntc2.storagescanner.desc2: Select an inventory from the list to access it. The buttons to the left of it allow you to change their order.
ntc2.storagescanner.desc3: Each inventory has a star next to them, which shows if they are &6routable&r. Routable inventories are the &6only inventory that items can be inserted into&r. Inventories at the top take priority.
ntc2.rftwire.title: The Latest in Redstone Wire Technology
ntc2.rftwire.subtitle: Make a Wire
ntc2.rftwire.desc: The &bWire&r works pretty much exactly like a line of Redstone dust. However, it can't turn corners, can go on walls and ceilings, and only moves signals from the blue end to the orange end. It also preserves signal strength.
ntc2.rftwirelessredstone.title: Wireless Redstone
ntc2.rftwirelessredstone.subtitle: Make a wireless redstone setup
ntc2.rftwirelessredstone.desc1: The &bRedstone Transmitter&r and &bRedstone Receiver&r work together to allow wireless redstone connections at any distance.
ntc2.rftwirelessredstone.desc2: &6Place down one, and then right-click it with another to link them together.&r A redstone signal entering the blue end of a Transmitter will make the orange end of the linked Receiver emit a full signal.
ntc2.rftwirelessredstone.desc3: Sneak click the Receiver with an empty hand to open the GUI, where you can enable &6Analog mode&r. In Analog mode, the Receiver will emit the same strength signal that entered the Transmitter, instead of emitting it at full strength.
ntc2.rftcounter.subtitle: Make a Counter
ntc2.rftcounter.desc1: The &bCounter&r will count the amount of redstone pulses it receives, then emit one when it gets to a defined amount, then starts over.
ntc2.rftcounter.desc2: Open the GUI to change the amount of pulses required.
ntc2.rfttimer.subtitle: Make a Timer
ntc2.rfttimer.desc: The &bTimer&r will emit a redstone pulse after a defined amount of ticks pass. You can change this amount in the Timer's GUI, as well as if receiving a redstone signal pauses it.
ntc2.rftsensor.subtitle: Make a Sensor
ntc2.rftsensor.desc1: The &bSensor&r will emit a redstone signal when certain conditions are met. Open the GUI to set those conditions.
ntc2.rftsensor.desc2: &6Block&r will emit a signal when a block is within the area. You can put a block in the top right slot to make it require specifically that block.
ntc2.rftsensor.desc3: &6Fluid&r will emit a signal when a fluid is within the area. You can put a bucket in the top right slot to make it require specifically that fluid.
ntc2.rftsensor.desc4: &6Growth&r will emit a signal when crops within the area are past a defined percentage grown. This percentage is typed into &6Number&r.
ntc2.rftsensor.desc5: &6Entities&r, &6Players&r, &6Hostile&r, and &6Passive&r will emit a signal when a defined amount of that type of entity are within the area.
ntc2.rftinvcheck.subtitle: Make an Inventory Checker
ntc2.rftinvcheck.desc1: The &bInventory Checker&r will emit a redstone signal if the inventory in front of it has a specified amount of a specified item is in a specified slot.
ntc2.rftinvcheck.desc2: You can also set it to ignore damage or use a tag instead of the specific item. You can also not set any item at all to allow it to work with anything.
ntc2.rftlogicgate.title: Truth Tables
ntc2.rftlogicgate.subtitle: Make a Logic
ntc2.rftlogicgate.desc: The &bLogic&r looks a lot more complex than it is. It has three inputs and one output. In its GUI, it shows every possible combination of signals, and you can set the output for each combination.
ntc2.rftanalog.title: Analogue?
ntc2.rftanalog.subtitle: Make an Analog
ntc2.rftanalog.desc1: The &bAnalog&r allows you to do complex calculations to modify the signal strength of the output based on the input and two variables.
ntc2.rftanalog.desc2: While standing on the &norange&r side of the Analog, the &6left side is variable A&r and the &6right is variable B&r. I is input and O is output.
ntc2.rftanalog.desc3: In the GUI, there are three equations for when A's signal strength is greater, equal to, or lower than B's.
ntc2.rftanalog.desc4: You can change each equation to multiply the input's strength by a factor, and then add a constant to it.
ntc2.rftseq.subtitle: Make a Sequencer
ntc2.rftseq.desc1: The &bSequencer&r's GUI allows you to set a pattern of offs and ons, and then cycles through them to emit signals.
ntc2.rftseq.desc2: You can set when and how it loops with the button that defaults to &6Once1&r; the tooltips should explain how they work.
ntc2.rftseq.desc3: You can also choose the amount of ticks the Sequencer pauses on each bit on, as well as set the sequence length to prematurely end it instead of lasting the whole 64 bits.
ntc2.rftdigit.title: Hexidigital
ntc2.rftdigit.subtitle: Make a Digit
ntc2.rftdigit.desc1: The &bDigit&r will show the hexidecimal value of the strength of the redstone signal it is given.
ntc2.rftdigit.desc2: For those who don't know, 0-9 in hexidecimal are just 0-9, but instead of 10 it has A, and instead of 11 it has B, and so on.
ntc2.rftenviro.title: Beacon? What's That?
ntc2.rftenviro.subtitle: Make an Environmental Controller
ntc2.rftenviro.desc1: The &bEnvironmental Controller&r allows you to give yourself certain effects, like speed, saturation or even &ocreative flight&r, in an area.
ntc2.rftenviro.desc2: Place up to 7 &bEnvironmental Modules&r in the left slots. At the top, set a radius and the max and min heights it works at. You can also optionally set a whitelist of players, or if it works on mobs.
ntc2.rftenviro.desc3: Fill the &bSyringe&r by attacking a mob with it. Each Module has a tooltip explaining what it does. Negative Modules only work on mobs, not players, so you'll have to set the Controller to target them.
ntc2.rftsyringe.title: And That's How I Lost My Medical License
ntc2.rftsyringe.subtitle: Make a Syringe
ntc2.rftsyringe.desc: Filled &bSyringes&r are required to craft Modules. To fill a Syringe, hold it in your hands and attack a mob.
ntc2.rftspawner.subtitle: Make a Spawner system
ntc2.rftspawner.desc1: The &bSpawner&r works in tandem with the &bMatter Beamer&r to spawn any mob, using a certain amount of three items.
ntc2.rftspawner.desc2: Place and power the Spawner, and then place and power three Matter Beamers nearby. Use a Smart Wrench on a Beamer then on the Spawner to bind them together.
ntc2.rftspawner.desc3: Place a full &bSyringe&r (which you fill by punching mobs with it) into the top right slot of the Spawner. There, you can see the items and the amount you need to spawn that mob.
ntc2.rftspawner.desc4: Mobs need &6key matter&r, &6bulk matter&r, and &6living matter&r. The key and bulk matters depend on the mob you're spawning, but living matter accepts any plant or animal drop.
ntc2.rftelevator.subtitle: Make an Elevator system
ntc2.rftelevator.desc1: &bElevators&r can smoothly send a platform up and down, bringing you with it. Place the bottom floor's first and give it power, then build the platform touching the Elevator's front face.
ntc2.rftelevator.desc2: Place the other floor's Elevators &6directly above it&r where you want the platform to stop at. When any Elevator gets a redstone signal, the platform will be sent to it. &6You only need to provide the bottom floor's Elevator with power.&r
ntc2.rftelevator.desc3: Elevators (and their passengers) will &6phase through any solid block in the way&r. You will still take &csuffocation damage&r, however.
ntc2.rftelevatorscreen.subtitle: Make an Elevator Button Screen Module
ntc2.rftelevatorscreen.desc1: It's frustrating to make a complex redstone circuit that allows you to send a signal to any Elevator from any other Elevator. You can use a &bElevator Button Screen Module&r to do this easier.
ntc2.rftelevatorscreen.desc2: Sneak right-click the Module on the Elevator floor you're on, then put it in a powered Screen nearby (&6Elevators can phase through Screens&r, so you don't have to put it outside the shaft). Repeat this for every floor.
ntc2.rftelevatorscreen.desc3: In the Module's GUI, you can choose the colors for the current floor and the other floors, the button style, the button &osize&r, and the names of 8 floors.
ntc2.rftelevatorscreen.desc4: Simply &6right-click one of the buttons&r on the Screen to be sent to that floor.
ntc2.rftshapecard.subtitle: Make a Shape Card
ntc2.rftshapecard.desc1: &bShape Cards&r are used in several machines in RFTools. They allow you to &6set the working area&r of those machines.
ntc2.rftshapecard.desc2: Right-click the Shape Card to set the shape and size, as well as the offset and if it's solid or hollow.
ntc2.rftcomposer.subtitle: Make a Composer
ntc2.rftcomposer.desc1: The &bComposer&r allows you to combine several Shape Cards into one final shape.
ntc2.rftcomposer.desc2: Put all the shapes you want to combine in the top slots, and the final Shape Card in the bottom.
ntc2.rftprojector.subtitle: Make a Projector
ntc2.rftprojector.desc1: The &bProjector&r will &6display a hologram of the Shape Card&r inserted into it.
ntc2.rftprojector.desc2: You can also set its angle, scale, and offset, as well as how a redstone signal from any side will effect it.
ntc2.rftbuilder.title: The Actual Best Thing
ntc2.rftbuilder.subtitle: Make a Builder
ntc2.rftbuilder.desc1: The &bBuilder&r will &6fill in an area&r set by a Shape Card &6using blocks from the inventory above it&r.
ntc2.rftbuilder.desc2: You can also &6sneak right-click a Shape Card onto it&r, then click two corners to set the working area.
ntc2.rftquarry.title: &lDiggy Diggy Hole&r
ntc2.rftquarry.subtitle: Make a Shape Card (Quarry)
ntc2.rftquarry.desc1: The &bShape Card (Quarry)&r works like a regular Shape Card, except Builders will &omine&r the working area instead of placing blocks.
ntc2.rftquarry.desc2: Blocks mined will insert their drops (as if mined with a regular pickaxe) into the inventory above the Builder. These blocks will be replaced with Dirt.
ntc2.rftquarry.desc3: This is honestly the &6best way to get resources&r the majority of the time. Put it down somewhere that won't annoy anyone, set it to the maximum possible size, and just let it run! Don't forget to set the shape to not be hollow.
ntc2.rftquarry.desc4: The &bShape Card (Clearing Quarry)&r works exactly the same as a regular Quarry card, except instead of replacing blocks with Dirt, it just leaves a hole.
ntc2.rftquarryupgrades.title: Shape Card (Quarry (Fortune (Clearing))
ntc2.rftquarryupgrades.subtitle: Make an upgraded Shape Card (Quarry)
ntc2.rftquarryupgrades.desc1: The &bShape Card (Fortune Quarry)&r works exactly like a regular Quarry card, except it &6applies a Fortune III enchantment to drops&r. Each block mined costs twice as much FE as a regular Quarry card.
ntc2.rftquarryupgrades.desc2: The &bShape Card (Silk Quarry)&r does the same, except with &6Silk Touch&r. Each mined block costs three times as much FE as a regular Quarry card.
ntc2.rftvoidcard.title: Shape Card (⬛⬛⬛⬛)
ntc2.rftvoidcard.subtitle: Make a Shape Card (Void)
ntc2.rftvoidcard.desc: The &bShape Card (Void)&r will &6destroy all blocks in its working area, &cleaving no drops&r. However, it requires &6zero FE&r per block, so this is great for clearing land.
ntc2.rftpump.title: Pump it Up!
ntc2.rftpump.subtitle: Make a Shape Card (Pump)
ntc2.rftpump.desc1: The &bShape Card (Pump)&r will collect any fluid in its working area and deposit it into the tank directly above. Fluids sources will be replaced with Dirt.
ntc2.rftpump.desc2: The &bShape Card (Clearing Pump)&r works exactly like a normal Pump card, except sources will not be replaced with Dirt.
ntc2.rftplacingfluids.subtitle: Make a Shape Card (Placing Fluids)
ntc2.rftplacingfluids.desc: The &bShape Card (Placing Fluids)&r will place fluids from the tank above itself in the working area.
ntc2.shieldprojector.title: False Walls, Drawbridges, and Wither Killers!
ntc2.shieldprojector.subtitle: Make a Shield Projector setup
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc1: RFTools' &bShields&r are extremely powerful and flexible devices. They can be nearly any shape, can look like any block, can allow certain things to pass through while blocking or damaging others, and can be disabled with a redstone signal. They are also entirely &6unbreakable, even by Withers&r!
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc2: Place &bShield Template&r blocks of any (single) color in the shape you want, make sure at least one of them is touching a &bShield Projector&r, and then use a &6Smart Wrench&r on the Projector. Templates of different colors will not interact with each other.
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc3: At the top of the Projector's GUI, you can make a list of &6rules&r.
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc4: At the top right, set what you want to happen to an entity type (whether they can pass, if they get damaged, etc).
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc5: Below that, set what entity type you want to effect (players, items, passive or hostile mobs, etc). If you chose player, you can specify which player in the text box below. Click &6Add&r to add that rule to the list.
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc6: These rules here will make Shields solid to hostile mobs and damage them, while letting items and the player Steve walk through them harmlessly.
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc7: At the bottom left, you can set what the Shields look like. You can change its colors, change its texure, and even set it to mimic a block you give it.
ntc2.shieldprojector.desc8: Additionally, you can make the Projector use a &6Shape Card&r instead of Shield Projectors, by placing the Card in the bottom left slot. You still have to click it with a Smart Wrench to enable it, however.
ntc2.rftoolsdimbok.subtitle: Get the RFTools Dimension Manual
ntc2.rftoolsdimbok.desc1: &eRFTools Dimensions&r is an add-on for RFTools that allow you to create dimensions to your specifications at great cost and risk.
ntc2.rftoolsdimbok.desc2: The &bRFtools Dimension Manual&r is the best source of information for how dimensions work.
ntc2.dimletparts.title: Dimlet Components
ntc2.dimletparts.subtitle: Get Dimlet components
ntc2.dimletparts.desc1: &bDimlets&r allow you to specify what kind of dimension you want to create; if you have no Dimlets, the dimension is completely random.
ntc2.dimletparts.desc2: Dimlets require components, which can be found in special structures that &6only generate in created dimensions&r. You can also find Dimlet Parcels in chests that give you random components.
ntc2.dimletworkbench.subtitle: Make a Dimlet Workbench
ntc2.dimletworkbench.desc1: You can craft Dimlets in the &bDimlet Workbench&r. On the right of the GUI is a searchable list of all possible Dimlets. Hover over a Dimlet to see what parts it needs.
ntc2.dimletworkbench.desc2: Put those Dimlet components in the slots on the left, and then click the Dimlet out of the list to try to craft it.
ntc2.dimletworkbench.desc3: You can also put a completed Dimlet in the top left slot and enable &6Extract&r to destroy it, getting some of its components.
ntc2.rftabsorbers.subtitle: Make Absorbers
ntc2.rftabsorbers.desc1: Some Dimlet recipes require filled &bAbsorbers&r. Absorbers are generally filled by placing them near the thing you want to absorb (current time, biome, liquids, etc) and letting them run. &6See their tooltips&r for more information.
ntc2.rftabsorbers.desc2: Of these, the &6Time Absorber&r is the strangest to get working, so I'll explain it: Place it down outside, and give it a redstone pulse around the time you want it to absorb. The next day, give it a redstone pulse around the same time to add another 10%% . It has a cooldown, so you can't just spam pulses to increase it. A &6Timer set to 24,000 ticks&r works perfectly, as that is the exact amount of ticks per Minecraft day (without sleeping).
ntc2.rftabsorbers.desc3: Mine a filled Absorber with a pickaxe to pick it up.
ntc2.rftenscriber.subtitle: Make a Dimension Enscriber
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc1: To actually &ocreate&r the dimension, you need a &bDimension Enscriber&r. Place an &bEmpty Dimension Tab&r in the bottom left to begin.
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc2: If you have no Dimlets, just go right ahead and click &6Store&r. That will create an entirely random dimension, with nothing set whatsoever.
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc3: If you &odo&r have Dimlets, put those in the slots at the top. &6Dimlet grammar&r, the order that Dimlets must be installed, can be a bit confusing:
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc4: &6Modifier Dimlets (like materials/fluids) must be entered &obefore&r&6 the things they modify.&r
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc5: So for instance, a Material Dimlet (Copper Ore) followed by a Feature Dimlet (HugeOrbs) will generate huge orbs made out of Copper Ore.
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc6: If two dimensions have identical Dimlets, they will go to the same dimension instead of creating another identical one. If you want to create two different dimensions with the same Dimlets, give it some Digit Dimlets.
ntc2.rftenscriber.desc7: You can also give dimensions names in the bottom left. Clicking &6Extract&r will take all the Dimlets out of it the Dimension Tab.
ntc2.rftdimensionbuilder.subtitle: Make a Dimension Builder
ntc2.rftdimensionbuilder.desc1: Place a Realized Dimension Tab into the slot in the &bDimension Builder&r to begin actually creating the dimension.
ntc2.rftdimensionbuilder.desc2: &6Dimensions require FE to be created, and more FE to run.&r Hover over the Realized Dimension Tab to see how much it needs to begin and run. More complex dimensions need more FE, so be careful when designing one.
